    It shall be unlawful for any person to take any cat or dog in his possession into any public park, school property, municipal building, restaurant or place of business, whether or not it is restrained by a leash, unless such dog is to be used in an official law enforcement task; provided, however, that when a blind, hearing impaired or physically handicapped person is accompanied by a dog which serves as a guide or leader for such person, neither the blind, hearing impaired or physically handicapped person, nor the dog, shall be denied the right of entry and use of facilities of any public place of accommodation as defined in 775 ILCS 5/5-101 if such dog is wearing a harness and such person presents credentials for inspection issued by a school for training guide dogs. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 3(B)) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 14-77. - Creating a nuisance. 
    No person shall allow cat, dog or other animal feces to accumulate in any yard, pen or premises in or upon which such animal shall be confined or kept so that it becomes offensive to those residing in the vicinity or a health hazard to the residing animal. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 3(C)) 
Sec. 14-78. - Removal of feces. 
    The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal and sanitary disposition of any excreta deposited by his animal anywhere in the village. When accompanying the animal outside his premises, the owner shall have visible on his person suitable means for the removal of such excreta which will then be placed in a refuse container for sanitary removal. The legally blind which are being led outside of their premises by a guide dog shall be exempt from this section. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 3(D)) 
Sec. 14-79. - Damage or injury. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow to cause any cat, dog or other animal to damage property other than his own, or to cause injury to another human being or animal. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 3(E)) 
Sec. 14-80. - During estrus (heat). 
    Any person in control of a female cat or dog during the period of estrus (heat) shall take all necessary steps to prevent male cats or dogs from coming in contact with such female animal, except for planned breeding. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 6) 
Sec. 14-81. - Dangerous or vicious dogs. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which has been found to be by ordinance a vicious dog unless such dog is kept in an enclosure. The only times that a vicious dog may be allowed out of the enclosure is if it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care of the dog or to comply with the order of a court of competent jurisdiction, provided that the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a tensile strength of 300 pounds and not exceeding three feet in length, and shall be under direct supervision of the owner or keeper of the dog. Any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog and which is not confined to an enclosure shall be impounded by a law enforcement agency and turned over to a licensed veterinarian to be properly euthanized. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper of a vicious dog to sell or give away such a dog. 
C.  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain a public nuisance by permitting any dangerous dog or other animal to leave the premises of its owner when not under control by a leash. 
D.  Guide dogs for the physically handicapped, sentry, guard or police owned are exempt from this section, provided that an attack or injury to a person occurs while the dog is performing duties as expected. 
E.  The administrator, state's attorney, or any citizen who has first-hand knowledge that a dangerous dog or other animal is located within the jurisdiction of the village may file a complaint to enjoin all personnel from maintaining or permitting such dog, to abate the same, and to enjoin the owner of such dog or animal from permitting the dangerous dog to leave his premises when not under control of a leash. Upon filing of a complaint in court, the court, if satisfied that a nuisance may exist, shall grant a preliminary injunction with bond in such an amount as the court may determine enjoining the defendant from maintaining such nuisance. If the existence of the nuisance is established, the owner of such dog or animal shall be in violation of this section, and in addition the court shall enter an order restraining the owner from maintaining such nuisance and may order that such dog or other animal be humanely euthanized. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 8) 
State Law reference- Dangerous or vicious dogs, 510 ILCS 5/15. 
Secs. 14-82-14-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HUMANE CARE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Humane Care for Animals Act, 510 ILCS 70/1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-111. - Removal of animal from negligent owner to registered veterinarian or shelter; impoundment. 
    When a community service officer or police officer finds a violation of this article, or a violation of any section of the Illinois Humane Care for Animals Act (510 ILCS 70/1 et seq.), that has resulted in an animal being in such condition that no remedy or corrective action by the owner is possible, or if the owner refuses to provide such remedy or corrective action, the community service officer or police officer may remove such animal from the property and impound the animal at a registered veterinarian or shelter for proper care and treatment. The owner or keeper of such animal shall be held strictly liable for all expenses incurred. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(L)) 
Sec. 14-112. - Injured or diseased animal in public places; removal; euthanization. 
    Any animal which is on any public way or place and which appears to be injured or diseased and for which no care is being provided, or any injured or diseased animal which has strayed onto private property shall be removed to the nearest humane society, pound or veterinarian willing to accept and treat the animal without guarantee of payment. If immediate removal shall not appear possible and all attempts to contact the animal's owner or veterinarian have been unsuccessful, the animal may be euthanized on the scene by the most humane method possible, unless the owner shall come forward and assume responsibility for immediate removal and care. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(I)) 
Sec. 14-113. - Owner's duties. 
    Each owner shall provide for each of his animals: 
1.  Sufficient quantity of good quality, wholesome food and water; 
2.  Adequate shelter and protection from the weather; 
3.  Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering; and 
4.  Humane care and treatment. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(A)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 70/3. 
Sec. 14-114. - Abuse or abandonment of animal. 
    No person or owner may beat, cruelly treat, torment, starve, overwork or otherwise abuse any animal. No owner may abandon any animal where it may become a public charge or may suffer injury, hunger or exposure. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(B), (E)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 70/3.01. 
Sec. 14-115. - Animal fighting. 
A.  No person may own, capture, breed, train or lease any animal which he knows or should know is intended for use in any show, exhibition, program or other activity featuring, or otherwise involving, a fight between such animal and any other animal or human, or the intentional killing of any animal for the purpose of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
B.  No person shall promote, conduct, carry on, advertise, collect money for or in any other manner assist or aid in the presentation for purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment, any show, exhibition, program or other activity involving a fight between two or more animals or any animal and human, or the intentional killing of any animal. 
C.  No person shall sell or offer for sale, ship, transport or otherwise move, or deliver or receive any animal which he knows or should know has been captured, bred or trained, or will be used, to fight another animal or human or be intentionally killed, for the purpose of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
D.  No person shall manufacture for sale, shipment, transportation or delivery any device or equipment which that person knows or should know is intended for use in any show, exhibition, program or other activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two or more animals, or any human and animal, or the intentional killing of any animal for purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
E.  No person shall own, possess, sell or offer for sale, ship, transport or otherwise move any equipment or device which such person knows or should know is intended for use in connection with any show, exhibition, program or activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two or more animals, or any animal and human, or the intentional killing of any animal for purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
F.  No person shall make available any site, structure or facility, whether enclosed or not, which he knows or should know is intended to be used for the purpose of conducting any show, exhibition, program or other activity involving a fight between two or more animals, or any animal and human, or the intentional killing of any animal. 
G.  No person shall attend or otherwise patronize any show, exhibition, program or other activity featuring or otherwise involving a fight between two or more animals, or any animal and human, or the intentional killing of any animal for the purposes of sport, wagering or entertainment. 
H.  No person shall tie or attach or fasten any live animal to any machine or device propelled by any power for the purpose of causing such animal to be pursued by a dog or dogs. This subsection shall apply only when such dog is intended to be used in a dog fight. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(C), (D)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 70/4.01. 
Sec. 14-116. - Offering animals as prizes. 
    No person shall give away or use any live animal or fowl as a prize for or as an inducement to enter any contest, game, competition or as an incentive to enter any business whereby the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(F)) 
Sec. 14-117. - Intentional poisoning or attempts to injure or kill domesticated animals. 
    No person shall knowingly poison, injure, harm, kill or make any attempt to do such acts to any domesticated animal. Licensed veterinarians may humanely euthanize any animal for the purpose of controlling disease or ending undue suffering. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(G)) 
Sec. 14-118. - Leaving unattended animals in vehicles. 
    No person shall leave any animal unattended in a motor vehicle, enclosed trailer, kennel, dog house, or any other type of container or structure where then animal does not have proper air circulation and the outside air temperature is 90 degrees or above. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(H)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Leaving animals in motor vehicles, 510 ILCS 70/7. 
Sec. 14-119. - Assisting animals struck by vehicles. 
    Any driver of a motor vehicle or other mobile conveyance which strikes an animal shall at once stop and render such assistance as may be possible and shall notify the animal's owner or, if not known, the village police department. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(J)) 
Sec. 14-120. - Leashing of animals to fixed objects. 
    No person shall leash any cat, dog or other animal to a fixed object unless such chains, ropes or leashes are so placed or attached that they cannot become entangled with another animal or object, and shall be of sufficient length in proportion to the size of the animal to allow the animal proper exercise and convenient access to food, water and shelter. Such leash shall be located so as not to allow such animal to trespass on public property or private property belonging to others, nor in such a manner as to cause harm or danger to persons or other animals. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 4, § 1(K)) 
Sec. 14-121. - Teasing, striking, tampering with, injuring or killing police dogs. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully and maliciously taunt, torment, tease, beat, strike or administer, or subject any desensitizing drugs, chemicals or substances to any dog used by law enforcement in the performance of such dog's functions or duties, or when placed in a kennel off duty, or to interfere or meddle with any such dog used by a law enforcement department or agency or any handler in the performance of the functions or duties of such department or agency. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously torture, mutilate, injure, disable, poison or kill any dog used by a law enforcement department or agency in the performance of the functions or duties of such department or when placed in kennel off duty. However, a police officer or veterinarian may perform euthanasia in emergency situations when delay would cause the dog undue suffering and pain. 
(Code 1972, ch. 11, art. 3, § 16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 510 ILCS 70/4.03, 4.04. 
Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; fees for buildings and building regulations, § 38-18; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; floods, ch. 46; erecting or moving buildings or structures, § 46-34; health and sanitation, ch. 50; signs, ch. 74; solid waste, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; subdivisions, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 98; vegetation, ch. 102. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6; statutory authority relative to buildings and construction, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Fees. 
    Fees for construction permits, zoning requests and other related activities shall be as established in section 38-18. 
Sec. 18-2. - Zoning. 
A.  Two letters to the president and board of trustees are required in order to request that a zoning board of appeals hearing be scheduled to consider the unique circumstances which necessitate the granting of variations from the zoning code of the Village of Norridge, and the specific variations which are being requested. Each letter must contain the name, address, and daytime and evening phone numbers of the petitioner and, if different, address of property to be considered. 
B.  Four stamped original sets of plans are required for such requests. Plans will include: Sketches with cover letter from architect, or drawings with architect's stamp and signature, showing what is being requested. In addition, all drawings much show pertinent dimensions (height, width, length and depth) as well as location on the property. A site plan must be included. 
C.  Any second floor addition requires the stamp and signature of an architect and a structural engineer. 
D.  Plat of survey, no older than one year from the date of application is required, showing all existing improvements, addition and structures. 
E.  Proof of ownership, i.e., Deed, Torrens certificate or title must be submitted. A complete, detailed, accurate legal description of property involved must appear on one or more of the following: Deed, title, Torrens, plat. 
F.  Ten packets of information, and the proper fee, must be submitted before the petition can be presented to the board of trustees to begin the zoning process. Each individual packet is to include the information required by this section. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 12, § 3) 
Secs. 18-3-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REAL ESTATE INSPECTION CERTIFICATES 

Sec. 18-31. - Required upon real estate transfer. 
A.  No owner, agent or person in charge of a dwelling or a structure used as a dwelling shall sell, quit claim, trade or otherwise transfer the same unless the dwelling or structure shall have been inspected and determined to be in compliance with the permitted uses as allowed by the village zoning code, shall have the required number of working smoke and CO detectors, shall have an approved backflow device if required by the Illinois Plumbing Code [Section 890.1140 d)] as may be amended from time to time, shall be determined not to be configured to allow any "clean" water into the sanitary sewers, and it shall have been determined that the owner is not in debt to the village, as evidenced by an inspection certificate issued by the building commissioner. 
B.  The requirement of obtaining an inspection certificate shall be mandatory on all transfers of ownership of or beneficial interest in all dwellings and structures in the village. The requirement shall further be reflected on all real estate title insurance reports conducted precedent to the transfer of ownership to give public notice of the mandatory inspection and issuance of the inspection certificate. A certified copy of this article shall be recorded with the county recorder of deeds, and copies shall be sent to all title insurance companies with notice that an inspection certificate is required on any transfer of ownership of real estate in the village. 
C.  An application for an inspection certificate can be secured from the office of the building department by any person owning real estate located within the village or his agent or nominee. The application for inspection certificate must be submitted to the building department during regular business hours not less than 21 days prior to any proposed sale, assignment or other transfer for any legal or beneficial interest of such real estate, or as soon as is practical, to allow sufficient time for the inspection required for the issuance of the inspection certificate. The cost of the inspection shall be paid by the applicant. 
1.  If such inspection establishes that the applicant and the property sought to be transferred are not in violation of the Code, the building commissioner shall issue an inspection certificate, evidence of which must be noted on the original deed or document of transfer in order to transfer property within the village. The inspection certificate shall indicate the date of inspection and that such dwelling complies with the Code. The building department shall keep a record of all inspection certificates on file in the office of the building department, and copies shall be furnished, upon request, to any person having a tenancy interest in the property. 
2.  If such inspection establishes that the applicant is in violation of the Code or the property does not comply with the Code, then no inspection certificate shall be issued. The applicant will be given an inspection report in a form adopted by the building department which indicates all deficiencies which were noted by the inspectors. When, and if, the applicant has corrected the deficiencies noted on the inspection report, he shall reapply for an inspection certificate. Such further inspection shall be limited to determination if the deficiencies noted on the inspection report have been cured. 
D.  Inspections shall not be required in the following conveyances, provided such conveyance in each case is accompanied by a certificate setting forth the facts or such other information as the village may require: 
1.  Transactions in which the deeds or assignments of beneficial interest, without additional consideration, to confirm, correct, modify, or supplement deeds or assignments of beneficial interest previously recorded or delivered. 
2.  Transactions made between any person acting in a fiduciary capacity to a successor fiduciary. 
3.  Transactions made upon the death of a joint-tenant or tenant-by-the-entirety to the survivor. 
E.  A fee in the amount established in section 38-18 shall be paid prior to the issuance of a certificate. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-H, § 1; Ord. No. 1299-00, § 1, 5-10-2000; Ord. No. 1592-07, §§ 2, 3, 10-10-2007; Ord. No. 1712-11, § 2, 7-27-2011; Ord. No. 1834-15, §§ 2, 3, 9-9-2015) 
Sec. 18-32. - Appeal of refusal to issue. 
A.  Any person whose application for an inspection certificate has been denied due to deficiencies noted in an inspection report or any person who is unable to comply with the provisions of this chapter with regard to obtaining an inspection certificate may appeal to the board of trustees and contest the findings contained on the inspection report or request that the requirements of this chapter be waived in his particular circumstances. 
B.  An appeal to the board of trustees must be perfected by filing a notice of appeal with the village clerk. Such notice of appeal must be filed within ten days from the date of issuance of the inspection report. The board of trustees may grant a variance from the requirements of the Code only when the applicant can prove by a preponderance of the evidence that: 
1.  Compliance with requirements of the Code will place an extreme hardship on the applicant; or 
2.  Physical conditions make compliance impossible. 
C.  The board of trustees shall hold a hearing on the appeal within seven days of the filing of the notice of appeal. It shall render a written decision at the close of the hearing or within seven days of the close of the evidence, at the latest. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-H, § 2) 
Sec. 18-33. - Warranty or guarantee not created. 
    Neither the inspection performed for the issuance of an inspection certificate nor the issuance of an inspection certificate shall be the basis for any liability on the part of the village. The inspection and the inspection certificate are an exercise of the village's police power and intended as additional tools to facilitate the enforcement of existing ordinances. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-H, § 4) 
Secs. 18-34-18-60. - Reserved.

    Section 916 Add the following section: Carbon monoxide Detectors 
    Section 916.0 Carbon Monoxide Detectors: 
    Section 916.1 Definitions 
    Carbon Monoxide Alarm: An electrical device, which meets the requirements of UL Standard 2034 for detecting and warning individuals of the presence of carbon monoxide. 
    Carbon Monoxide Monitor: An electrical device for detecting and warning individuals of the presence of carbon monoxide. These devices do not meet UL Standard 2034 because they detect and alarm smaller quantities of carbon monoxide then UL 2034 allows. 
    Section 916.2 General 
1.  Carbon monoxide alarms where required by this code shall meet the current UL Standard 2034 or its equivalent. Carbon monoxide alarms shall be installed per the requirements of NFPA 720. 
2.  Carbon monoxide monitors where allowed by this code shall be installed and maintained per the manufacturer's recommendations. 
3.  All carbon monoxide monitors wiring must be in its own raceway. 
    Section 916.3 Where required-living spaces 
1.  Carbon monoxide alarms are required in any building with sleeping facilities that relies on combustion of fossil fuel for heat, ventilation, hot water, or fireplace within the building, and for buildings with attached garages. 
a.  Exception No. 1 Carbon monoxide alarms may be replaced by carbon monoxide monitors where individuals, whose age, pregnancy or chronic health conditions make them adversely susceptible to low levels of carbon monoxide. 
2.  In buildings with multi-sleeping facilities, with completely separate fossil fueled steam or hot water heating appliances are located in an area completely separated from the sleeping quarters, the carbon monoxide alarm does not need to be in the sleeping area but must have one alarm in the fossil fueled appliances area. 
3.  Existing buildings, with sleeping facilities, that are renovated or altered and the work would normally require a City permit to accomplish, after adoption of this ordinance shall be required to install a carbon monoxide alarm per this ordinance. 
4.  Existing buildings with sleeping facilities that replace a furnace or hot water heater with a fossil fueled furnace or hot water heater or install a fireplace shall be required to install a carbon monoxide alarm per this ordinance. 
    Section 917 Add the following: False Fire Alarm Service Charge: 
    Section 917.1 Charge: A charge of five hundred dollars ($500) per call shall be made to the user of automatic fire alarm facilities, installed and maintained by others, which initiates a response by the Village of Norridge for a false alarm being given or transmitted by these facilities to the District. 
    Section 917.2 Time period: This charge shall be for each false alarm transmitted and responded to by the Village of Norridge during any ninety (90) day period commencing with the third (3 rd ) false alarm transmitted during any ninety (90) day period, whether caused by malfunctioning or intentionally or negligently misused or abused facilities or equipment, and which results in the fire suppression and/or rescue apparatus and equipment being unnecessarily called to the property in response thereto. All charges shall be paid within thirty (30) days of the mailing or delivery of an invoice. Failure to pay may result in Village Licenses being revoked or suspended.

Section 202 Add the following new definition: Grading plan, A grading plan shall consist of the following: 
1.  Signature and seal by an Illinois licensed professional engineer. 
2.  Elevation of grades at the adjacent houses/garages. 
3.  Ground elevations at the corners, at twenty five (25) foot intervals along the property line, and spot elevations at critical locations. 
4.  The plan shall show existing contours for the lot and adjacent properties on one-foot contours. 
5.  The plan shall include information on adjacent properties to show contours, drainage courses, structure location and foundation elevation within fifteen (15) feet of the subject property. 
6.  Finished grade at foundation shall be six (6) inches below top of foundation, brick ledge, etc. 
7.  Existing public utilities (storm, sanitary, water, gas, etc.) must be shown on the plan. 
8.  Proposed location of the sump pump discharge shall be indicated on the site plan to be placed on a splash block or connected directly to on-site storm sewer. 
9.  All down spouts must be shown on the plan indicating that each to be placed on splash blocks or connected directly to storm sewer. 
10.  The plan shall show proposed building top of foundation, and elevations of proposed finished ground grades at all significant points around the proposed building. Along with elevations of garage slab, patio, private sidewalk and driveway at various locations. 
11.  The proposed elevation of the principal residential structure should be in conformity with the grade adjacent, neighboring property and right-of-way. 
12.  Site plan must include soil erosion and sediment control measures with detailed drawings. 
13.  Show direction of drainage flow (?) on the property (water to flow to a catch basin or to the street). 
14.  Since water may not drain on to any adjacent property, a catch basin may be required that is connected to the Village storm sewer system. If a catch basin is required, they must be shown on the grading plan. 
15.  Show elevations of public sidewalk and top of curb and flow line of curb at various locations along the street side of the property.

It shall be connected to the village storm sewer through a cored opening with a Type C inlet. All lots shall be provided with a grading plan.

Section R326 Add the following section: Outside entrance: An outside entrance cannot be the entrance to a basement or to a second story without an interior stairway. 
Section R327 Add a new section R327 New sidewalks, any new single-family residence or second floor addition must replace the main city sidewalk in front of the residence. 
Section R402.1 WOOD FOUNDATIONS: Wood foundations or footings are not allowed in the Village of Norridge. This also eliminates all other sections, sub sections, tables or charts, which reference the use of wood footings or foundations. 
Section R405.1.2 Sump pumps: The sump pump installed in a foundation drainage system shall be properly sized for the lift from the bottom of the sump pit to the elevation of the sump pump discharge hose. 
Section R501.3 ENGINEERED FLOOR JOISTS: Add the following: All floor systems installed over a basement shall have drywall or a sprinkler system installed when engineered joists such as open web trusses or "I" joists are used. 
Section R502.2 DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION: Add the following: All attached decks and floor systems shall be securely bolted to the primary structure. Lumber used in the floor system shall be a minimum of # 2 and better construction. All bolts, hangers and flashings shall be compatible with the lumber being used. 
Section R506.1 Concrete flatwork General Change 3 1/2 inches to 5 inches and add the following sentence: All outside flatwork on private property shall be a minimum of 5 inches thick. All driveways and basements shall have wire mesh or fiber mesh. 
All slabs shall be formed using a minimum of a 2 × 6 form. 
All slabs, sidewalks, driveways and patios shall be formed so the concrete is not above the top of the foundation and below the exterior finish. 
Section R801.4 Add the following: ROOF DRAINAGE: Where roof drainage is installed the discharge elbow shall not face the neighbors property.

Section 920 Add the following section: Carbon Monoxide Detectors 
Section 920.0 Carbon Monoxide Detectors: 
Section 920.1 Definitions 
Carbon Monoxide Alarm An electrical device, which meets the requirements of UL Standard 2034 for detecting and warning individuals of the presence of carbon monoxide. 
Carbon Monoxide Monitor An electrical device for detecting and warning individuals of the presence of carbon monoxide. These devices do not meet UL Standard 2034 because they detect and alarm smaller quantities of carbon monoxide then UL 2034 allows. 
Section 920.2 General 
1.  Carbon monoxide alarms where required by this code shall meet the current UL Standard 2034 or its equivalent. Carbon monoxide alarms shall be installed per the requirements of NFPA 720. 
2.  Carbon monoxide monitors where allowed by this code shall be installed and maintained per the manufacturer's recommendations. 
3.  All carbon monoxide monitor wiring must be in its own raceway. 
Section 920.3 Where required-living spaces 
1.  Carbon monoxide alarms are required in any building with sleeping facilities that relies on combustion of fossil fuel for heart, ventilation, hot water, or fireplace within the building, and for buildings with attached garages. 
a.  Exception No. 1 Carbon monoxide alarms may be replaced by carbon monoxide monitors where individuals, whose age, pregnancy or chronic health conditions make them adversely susceptible to low levels of carbon monoxide. 
2.  In buildings with multi-sleeping facilities, with completely separate fossil fueled steam or hot water heating appliances are located in an area completely separated from the sleeping quarters, the carbon monoxide alarm does not need to be in the sleeping area but must have one alarm in the fossil fueled appliances area. 
3.  Existing buildings, with sleeping facilities, that area renovated or altered and the work would normally require a City permit to accomplish, after adoption of this ordinance shall be required to install a carbon monoxide alarm per this ordinance. 
4.  Existing buildings with sleeping facilities that replace a furnace or hot water heater with a fossil fueled furnace or hot water heater or install a fireplace shall be required to install a carbon monoxide alarm per this ordinance. 
Section 921 Add the following: False Fire Alarm Service Charge: 
Section 921.1 Charge: A charge of five hundred dollars ($500) per call shall be made to the user of automatic fire alarm facilities, installed and maintained by others, which initiates a response by the Village of Norridge for a false alarm being given or transmitted by these facilities to the District. 
Section 921.2 Time period: This charge shall be for each false alarm transmitted and responded to by the Village of Norridge during any ninety (90) day period commencing with the third (3 rd ) false alarm transmitted during any ninety (90) day period, whether caused by malfunctioning or intentionally or negligently misused or abused facilities or equipment, and which results in a the fire suppression and/or rescue apparatus and equipment being unnecessarily called to the property in response thereto. All charges shall be paid within thirty (30) days of the mailing or delivery of an invoice. Failure to pay may result in Village Licenses being revoked or suspended. 
Section 1006.3 Add the following: All emergency light wiring shall be in its own raceway. 
Section 1011.5.1 Add the following: All exit signs shall have red letters. 
Section 1011.5.3.1 Add the following: All exit light wiring must be in its own raceway. 
Section 3204.3 Add the following: The storage of cryogenics outside is not allowed. 
Section 3404.2.9.6.1 Add the following: The storage of flammable liquids outside is not allowed. 
Section 3406.2.4.4 Add the following: The storage of flammable liquids outside is not allowed. 
Section 3804.2 Add the following: The storage of liquefied petroleum gases outside is not allowed. The storage of propane for sale shall comply with the provisions of this chapter.

SECTION 19 CONSTRUCTION WORK 
1.  Construction hours: Construction. Including mass grading and excavations shall only be allowed during the following hours: 
Monday-Saturday 7:00 AM to 8:00 PM 
Sunday 9:00 AM to 6:00 PM 
2.  Dust Control: During grading, excavation and construction, dust control measures shall be taken, as needed, such measures to include regular use of water trucks, and wets saws. 
3.  Streets: During grading, excavation and construction, the streets shall be kept clean and free from construction debris. Streets shall be cleaned at least daily and immediately after mud or other debris has been deposited on the street. 
4.  Trash Containers: Approved trash containers for construction debris shall be present on-site and shall be maintained as needed during construction of the proposed structure or improvements. 
5.  Provide a six-foot chain link fence around all construction areas. The use of other fence material is not allowed. The fence shall be removed at the discretion of the building department. 
6.  No dumping or placing of any material, waste material or spoils onto the street or alley is allowed. 
7.  All construction sites shall have proper sanitation facilities. 
8.  All construction sites residential and commercial shall have an address posted during construction.

ARTICLE IV. - SOLAR HEATING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Solar heating means a system designed to convert solar radiation to thermal energy and through the use of this energy to meet all or part of a structure's heating and domestic hot water requirements. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-92. - Installation and material. 
    Solar system design shall attempt to reduce corrosion by avoiding dissimilar metals or by using a getter to reduce galvanic action. The use of PVC, ABS or other plastic piping material is prohibited, except as permitted by the building commissioner. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 6) 
Sec. 18-93. - Protection of potable water supply. 
    No solar heating system that has the potential to contaminate (by any failure mode) the potable house or municipal water supply will be permitted. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 7) 
Secs. 18-94-18-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 18-111. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to proceed with the construction, installation, enlargement or alteration of any device intended to provide primary or secondary heating to any building or structure in the village by use of solar heating, unless a building permit has been issued by the building commissioner or his duly appointed representative. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 2) 
Sec. 18-112. - Fees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to proceed with the construction, installation, enlargement or alteration of any solar heating device without paying the required fee established in section 38-18. If, in the opinion of the building commissioner, the plans submitted require additional review by an independent, qualified engineer or architect, the cost of this service shall be borne by the permittee. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 3) 
Sec. 18-113. - Architectural, structural and engineering seals. 
    No plans shall be approved for a permit unless such plans are signed and sealed by an architect licensed to practice architecture, as approved by the Illinois Architecture Practice Act of 1989, (225 ILCS 305/1 et seq.), a structural engineer licensed to practice engineering, as provided by the Structural Engineering Practice Act of 1989, (225 ILCS 340/1 et seq.) or by a professional engineer licensed to practice engineering, as provided by the state department of registration and education. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 4) 
Sec. 18-114. - Plans and drawings. 
    Plans shall be drawn at a scale of not less than one-eighth of an inch to a foot and shall contain the following information: 
1.  Complete details indicating size, location and materials used as structural members supporting the solar collectors and storage areas. 
2.  All details relating to construction of a proposed solar system, including size, type of material, location of all duct work, heat exchangers, solar collectors, storage areas, piping, fans, valves, pumps, insulation details for floors, walls and ceilings or any other related details that may be required by the building commissioner. 
3.  Calculations indicating the method used to determine size of collectors and projected heating percentage the proposed solar system can be expected to conserve in a yearly span. 
4.  All collectors shall be of the roof type, nontracking. Collectors shall not exceed the height of the established ridge board on the residence. They shall not exceed 50 percent of the roof area upon which they are mounted. Collectors may be of the reflective or adsorptive types. Ground-mounted collectors are not permitted. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-C, § 5) 
Secs. 18-115-18-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1522-05, § 3, adopted Sept. 14, 2005, repealed Art. V, §§ 18-141, 18-142, which pertained to Property Maintenance Code and derived from Code 1972, ch. 20-G, §§ 1, 3; Ord. No. 1462-03, § 2, adopted Oct. 22, 2003. The user's attention is directed to §§ 18-78, 18-79. 

Secs. 18-141-18-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FENCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Statutory authority over fences, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-1. 

Sec. 18-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fence means a physical barrier erected to separate properties on a lot and a street. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 1, ch. 18, art. 2, § 53) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-172. - Permit required. 
    The owner of any residential property desiring to erect and maintain a fence upon such property shall file an application for a fence permit with the building commissioner or his duly appointed representative. Such application shall be accompanied by an accurate plat or sketch of the premises indicating thereon the proposed fence location. A fee in the amount specified in section 38-18 shall be charged for such permit. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 3) 
Sec. 18-173. - Location. 
A.  No fence shall be erected between the established front building line and the front property lot line in any area zoned for residential purposes. 
B.  No fence shall hereafter be constructed, nor shall any existing constructed fence be altered or enlarged to protrude any closer to the street line than the front setback line of the building. 
C.  It shall be unlawful to construct a fence of any height in the parkway. 
D.  The owner shall be obligated to locate the fence entirely within the property lines and positioned in such a way that proper maintenance can be effected without ingress onto the adjacent property. No fence shall hereafter be constructed, nor shall any existing fence be altered or added to, causing two fences to be back to back or on the same property line. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 1, § 30, ch. 6, art. 6, § 4(b), (c), ch. 18, art. 2, § 53(d), (e)) 
Sec. 18-174. - Wind pressure resistance; specifications. 
    Fences shall be designed and constructed to resist horizontal wind pressures of not less than 30 pounds per square foot, in addition to all other forces to which they may be subjected. 
(Code 1972, ch. 18, art. 2, § 53(b)) 
Sec. 18-175. - Finished side to face outward. 
    The finished side of any fence shall face outward or toward the public view. 
(Code 1972, ch. 18, art. 2, § 53(f)) 
Sec. 18-176. - Height. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or cause to have erected a fence that exceeds six feet in height. This height shall be established from the existing grade. Decorative posts, spindles, lattice work and chains shall be included when computing the height of the fence. Where a lot line is adjacent to nonresidentially zoned property, there shall be an eight-foot limit on the height of the fence along such lot line. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 4(a)) 
Sec. 18-177. - Construction materials. 
    Fences may be constructed of any durable material such as wood, metal, stone, brick or suitable synthetic material, and shall be designed to resist horizontal wind pressures of not less than 30 pounds per square foot. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 2) 
Sec. 18-178. - Openings in solid fences. 
    Fences (with less than 25 percent openings or aperture) shall not be permitted. For the purpose of computing the percentage of openings, gates or doors shall not be considered. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 4(d)) 
Sec. 18-179. - Barbed wire. 
    Fences constructed of barbed wire, spike-nail or other pointed instrument are prohibited. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 4(e)) 
Sec. 18-180. - Electrically charged fencing. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain or construct any fence charged with electric current. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 1, § 29) 
Sec. 18-181. - Patio fence. 
    A permit is required, but no fee shall be charged, for a patio fence. Barriers such as those used with a patio shall not exceed 15 feet in length nor eight feet in height, and must be located at least three feet from the property lines, be within three feet of the patio, and not run adjacent to an existing fence. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 6, § 4) 
Secs. 18-182-18-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SWIMMING POOLS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Statutory authority over swimming pools, 65 ILCS 5/11-30-9; swimming Pool and Bathing Beach Act, 210 ILCS 125/1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private swimming pool and wading pool mean any swimming pool or wading pool, whether indoors or outdoors and whether above or below the surface of the ground, or both, intended to contain water for swimming, have an inside wall depth at any point of more than 24 inches, or a surface area exceeding 250 square feet, located at a private residence, used and intended to be used not by the public, but solely by the owner or occupant and his family and friends. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-212. - Enforcement; right to inspect. 
    The building commissioner is hereby charged with the duty of enforcing this article. For this purpose, he and his inspectors are hereby authorized to enter any premises in the village to inspect any private swimming pool at any reasonable hour. The health officer is hereby authorized to enter upon any premises, private or public, to take such samples of water from such pools at such times as it may deem necessary and to require the owner or operator to comply with rules and regulations pertaining to private swimming pools promulgated by either the board of health or the building commissioner, or the requirements of this article. The building commissioner shall have the power to abate or cause a suspension of the use of such private swimming pool until such time as the same is, in the opinion of the health officer, no longer a menace or a hazard to health, safety or morals. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 14) 
Sec. 18-213. - Regulations. 
    The building commissioner may promulgate regulations for the construction, alteration, operation and maintenance of pools to carry out the provisions and purpose of this article. The regulations may provide for the use of materials, devices, structures and appurtenant equipment substantially equivalent to that required in this article, so long as the degree of protection is not less than the protection provided in this article. All such regulations shall be designed to further public health or public safety. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 16) 
Sec. 18-214. - Compliance with requirements of state department of public health. 
    In the construction, operation and maintenance of any private swimming pool state laws and the rules, regulations and requirements of the state department of public health shall be observed. In the event of any conflict between the provisions of this article and any provision of state law or requirement, rule or regulation of the state department of public health, the provision imposing the higher standard or the more stringent requirement shall be controlling. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 12) 
Sec. 18-215. - Permit. 
A.  Required. No person shall construct, install or alter any private swimming pool in the village unless a permit therefor shall first have been obtained from the building commissioner. 
B.  Application. The application for a construction permit shall be in writing in the form prescribed by the building commissioner. Such application shall contain information as shall be required by the building commissioner and the health officer for a proper understanding of the proposed work. 
C.  Submission of plans and specifications. Clear and detailed drawings, plans and specifications for the construction, installation or alteration of any pool and appurtenances shall be presented to the building commissioner and the health officer for examination and approval as to proper location, construction and use. All drawings shall be complete, showing the lot lines, and shall include information pertaining to fence construction, water supply system and all equipment and appurtenances to the pool. 
D.  Review of plans and specifications. The building commissioner shall review such plans and specifications to determine whether they comply with the provisions of this article and with reasonable standards of swimming pool construction for the protection of the public, their health, safety and morals. 
E.  Fee. The fee for a permit to construct a pool shall be an amount specified in section 38-18 for each 250 square feet or fraction thereof of surface area to be contained within the proposed pool, as determined by the plans and specifications submitted with the application for a construction permit, and other fees as required by the building code of the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, §§ 1, 13) 
Sec. 18-216. - Location. 
    No portion of a pool or any of its equipment or appurtenances shall be located at a distance of less than six feet from any property line or structure or accessory structure. A pool shall also comply with all minimum setback requirements of the village zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 15; Ord. No. 1429-02, § 2, 12-11-2002) 
Sec. 18-217. - Enclosures. 
A.  Every owner, purchaser under contract, lessee, tenant or licensee of land within the village upon which is situated a private swimming pool shall at all times maintain, on the lot or premises upon which such private swimming pool is located, a fence or other structure completely surrounding such pool, not less than six feet in height, with no gaps or apertures, other than doors or gates, with any dimensions greater than four inches. All gates or doors opening through such fence or enclosure shall be equipped with self-closing and self-latching devices placed at the top of such gates or doors and made inaccessible to small children. Such devices shall be so designed as to be capable of keeping such doors or gates securely closed at all times when not in actual use. 
B.  All such gates shall be kept locked when not in use. The building commissioner may make modifications in individual cases, upon a showing of good cause with respect to the height, nature or location of the fence, wall, gates or latches, or the necessity therefor, provided that the protections as sought under this section are not reduced thereby. The board of health may permit other protective devices or structures to be used so long as the degree of protection afforded by the substitute devices or structures is not less than the protection afforded by the wall, fence, gate and latch described in this section. The building commissioner shall allow a reasonable period within which to comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 3) 
Sec. 18-218. - Walks. 
    A walk area not less than four feet wide shall be installed entirely around a pool except in the case of a portable aboveground installation. The walk shall be of impervious materials and shall have a definite pitch away from the pool of at least one-half inch to the foot. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 4) 
Sec. 18-219. - Water supply. 
    Every person in possession of land on which a private swimming pool is located shall have such pool conform with the following regulations: 
1.  The water supply shall be from a connection to a public water supply and shall consist of a permanent rigid system of piping having an airgap delivery connection located not less than six inches vertically above the flood rim of the pool. 
2.  No private swimming pool in excess of 5,000 gallons capacity shall be installed or used without a recirculating and filtering system having a minimum hourly capacity equal to the pool volume divided by ten. Sufficient filter area shall be provided to filter the entire pool volume in 18 hours at a rate not exceeding three gallons per square foot of filter area per minute. 
3.  No water from any swimming pool shall be discharged directly into the sanitary or storm sewer system. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 5) 
Sec. 18-220. - Electrical requirements. 
A.  No current carrying electrical conductors shall cross private residential swimming pools, either overhead or underground or within 15 feet of such pools. 
B.  All metal fences, enclosures or railing or lighting fixtures near or adjacent to private residential swimming pools, which might become electrically alive as a result of or contact with broken conductors or from any other cause, shall be effectively grounded. 
C.  All electrical devices in a swimming pool shall be effectively grounded and connected to a ground fault interrupter. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 6) 
Sec. 18-221. - Sanitation. 
    Every private swimming pool shall be so designed and constructed as to facilitate cleaning and shall be maintained and operated in such a manner as to be clean and sanitary at all times. All pools shall be thoroughly cleaned at least once each week in a manner and by the use of such disinfecting agents or cleansing materials as may be required by the board of health. All such pools shall be emptied and the water therein completely changed at least twice each week. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 7) 
Sec. 18-222. - Interference with enjoyment of property rights. 
    No private swimming pool shall be so located, designed, operated or maintained as to interfere unduly with the enjoyment of the property rights of owners of property adjoining the private swimming pool or located in the neighborhood. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 8) 
Sec. 18-223. - Shielding lights. 
    Lights used to illuminate any private swimming pool shall be so arranged and shaded as to reflect light away from adjoining premises. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 9) 
Sec. 18-224. - Unnecessary noise. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued at any private swimming pool any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others. In the operation of a private swimming pool, the use or permitting the use or operation of any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing of the persons who are in the private swimming pool premises shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1972, ch. 10, § 10) 
Secs. 18-225-18-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - UNSAFE OR DANGEROUS BUILDINGS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Unsafe property, 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1 et seq. 

Sec. 18-251. - Prohibited generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessor or agent to permit a building to be in an unsafe, dangerous or uncompleted condition, or to abandon such building. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-A, § 1) 
Sec. 18-252. - Repair and demolition requirements. 
    The village board may demolish, repair or cause the demolition or repair of dangerous or unsafe buildings or uncompleted or abandoned buildings within the village limits. No building may be boarded up or otherwise enclosed. The president and board of trustees shall apply to the county circuit court for an order authorizing such action to be taken with respect to any such building if the owner, including the lienholders of record, after at least 15 days' written notice by mail so to do, have failed to put such building in a safe condition or to demolish it. Where, upon diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of the owner of such building, including the lienholders of record, is not ascertainable, notice mailed to the person in whose name such real estate was last assessed is sufficient notice under this section. The cost of such demolition or repair incurred by the village is recoverable from the owner of such real estate and is a lien thereon, which lien is superior to all existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes; provided, however, that within 60 days after such repair or demolition, the village shall file notice of lien of such cost and expense incurred in the office of the county recorder of deeds or in the office of the county registrar of titles if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens system. The notice must consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
1.  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification; 
2.  The amount of money representing the cost and expenses incurred; and 
3.  The dates when the cost and expense were incurred by the village. 
Upon payment of the cost and expenses by the owner of or persons interested in the property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village, and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in case of mortgages or mechanic's liens. Suit to foreclose this lien must be commenced within three years after the date of filing a notice of lien. 
(Code 1972, ch. 20-A, § 2) 
Secs. 18-253-18-280. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CONDOMINIUM AND COOPERATIVE CONVERSIONS 

Sec. 18-281. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to all divisions of land or property into residential condominium units and to conversion of multifamily residential property to cooperatives and to the construction of new condominium and cooperative buildings. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-282. - Definitions. 
    The terms and words used shall have the definitions set forth in the Condominium Property Act of Illinois. Cooperative conversions shall mean the situation when a building is converted to cooperative ownership, legal title to the building is transferred to an apartment corporation which has been formed to take over ownership of the property. The residents of a cooperative do not actually buy their individual units. Rather, they buy the shares in the apartment corporation allocated to a particular unit. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-283. - Subdivision plat of condominiums. 
    A subdivision plat of any conversion into or construction of condominium units shall require village board approval as set forth in the subdivision regulations in chapter 86, article II of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-284. - Condominium plat approval; recording. 
    No condominium plat shall be recorded without the prior approval of the village, nor permits issued for the construction or conversion of the same without said approval. No plat of condominium shall be recorded without complying with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-285. - Condominium and cooperative requirements. 
    All conversions into condominiums or cooperatives or construction of new condominiums or cooperatives shall follow the regulations set forth in the Condominium Property Act and, in addition, shall comply with the following: 
1.  No unit in any condominium or shares in a cooperative may be sold or transferred after the effective date of this chapter unless a certificate of inspection has been issued by the building commissioner stating that said condominium unit or cooperative complies with the conversion element provisions of this chapter. For that purpose, the applicant shall submit as-built drawings of the architect and site development certified by a registered architect. 
2.  No certificate of inspection shall be issued, no sale of a condominium or cooperative unit shall be made, and no condominium plat approved where the requirements of any ordinance of the village concerning any zoning, building, or subdivision provisions are currently not being complied with by the building located on the property and by the common area. 
3.  No building or land previously non-conforming (legal or illegal) or granted a variation to any zoning, building or subdivision ordinance shall be converted into condominiums or a cooperative building unless the current requirements of the applicable ordinance are met. 
4.  All condominiums and cooperatives shall comply with the current regulations, including open space and parking requirements for the land use zone in which they are located. Provided, however, that there shall be at least two and one half parking spaces per condominium unit in each condominium building and for each unit in a cooperative building. 
5.  All residential condominiums and cooperatives shall comply with the village version of the BOCA National Fire Prevention Code of 1996. 
6.  A separate gas, electric and water meter and shut-off valve shall be provided for each unit. In a residential condominium or cooperative, a common water meter may be provided for each building. Each unit shall have separate hot water heater, furnace, and if provided, air conditioning system. 
7.  Common garbage and trash disposal containers shall be provided in a location screened from view in an area to avoid a minimum of noise and smell. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-286. - Common elements. 
    All condominium associations and cooperative corporations shall be responsible for traffic and parking control, snow removal, signing, sewers, water lines and lighting. The village shall have the right of easement to enter such common areas for the purpose of emergency for fire, police and enforcement of its ordinances and the plat shall so provide. Such common area shall remain the property of the condominium or cooperative, and the village shall not accept a dedication of these elements or the responsibility of maintenance. The association or corporation shall maintain the public area and parkway in a clean condition, free of debris, leaves and trash. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-287. - Certificate of inspection. 
    Once a certificate of inspection has been issued, no new certificate of inspection need be secured for the sale of any unit for which a certificate of inspection has been previously issued. Provided, however, that if the unit or interest in the cooperative is resold, a further certificate must be obtained from the village. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Sec. 18-288. - Inspection fees. 
    The fees for inspection shall be paid by the applicant or the owner association or corporation or owner, if the village is compelled to inspect to insure compliance with this chapter. The fee shall be $100.00, plus $30.00 for each unit. 
(Ord. No. 1394-02, § 1, 3-14-2002; Ord. No. 1409-02, § 1, 8-14-2002) 
Secs. 18-289-18-299. - Reserved.

Secs. 18-300-18-319. - Reserved. 
Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquor, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; fees for businesses, § 38-22; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 66; secondhand goods, ch. 70; taxation, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art VII, § 6; general authority over businesses, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Nuisances. 
    No business, licensed or not, shall be so conducted or operated as to constitute a nuisance in fact. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 11, ch. 18, art. 2, § 26) 
State Law reference- Authority to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Closing hours generally. 
A.  No business establishments within the village shall conduct business from 12:01 a.m. to 6:00 a.m. with the following exceptions: 
1.  A business licensed to sell alcoholic liquor under chapter 6 of this Code are set forth in chapter 6 of this Code. 
2.  A business primarily engaged in the sale and dispensing of gasoline, diesel fuel or ethanol for transportation purposes may elect twenty-four-hour operation if, and only if, it is not within 200 feet of a residence and it does no mechanical or tire repair work of any kind on the premises between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
3.  A retail pharmacy which dispenses prescription medication may elect 24-hour operation, if, and only if, there is a licensed pharmacist on duty at all times. 
4.  A business primarily engaged in food preparation and sales. 
5.  A health club or exercise facility with a facility in excess of 25,000 square feet, a swimming pool, commercial exercise equipment which does not serve or allow any alcohol on its premises. 
B.  Any business claiming an exception listed hereinabove must first provide notice to the business license administrator of an election to remain open for any period between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 2(d), ch. 18, art. 2, § 59; Ord. No. 1746-12, § 2, 6-13-2012; Ord. No. 1754-12, § 2, 9-26-2012) 
Secs. 22-3-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS LICENSES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General licensing authority, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-1. 

Sec. 22-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in a business requiring a license without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 1) 
Sec. 22-32. - Application; term; fees. 
A.  All business establishments with buildings or premises in the village shall file with the village clerk, or such other officer as he may designate, an application for a license to operate the business establishment in the village on or before April 30 of each year or at such time as the business establishment desires to commence operation in the village. Application forms for such licenses shall be made available by the village. 
B.  Subject to the terms and provisions of this chapter, the village clerk, or such officer as he may designate, shall issue a license to permit the operation of the business establishment in the village for a period of one year which shall begin on May 1 of the year for which such license is issued and terminate on April 30 of the next year. No license shall be issued at the yearly rate of license fees except for the full license year; provided, however, that when such license is issued on or after November 1, the license fee shall be one-half of the yearly license fee for the unexpired term of the license year. 
C.  The required fee for each license issued shall be collected in full at the time of its issuance and delivery. In no event shall any rebate or refund be made of any license fee, or part, by reason of the death of the licensee or by any reason of nonuse of the license or discontinuance of the operation of the business establishment. Unless expressly provided to the contrary, all license fees shall become a part of the general corporate fund. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 2(a)-(c)) 
Sec. 22-33. - Record required; signing, posting. 
    The village clerk, or such other officer as he may designate, shall cause a record to be kept of all business establishments and business licenses as may be necessary for the purpose of classifying, inspecting, serving and licensing all business establishments in the village. Subject to the terms and provisions of this chapter and upon payment in full of the required license fee, the village shall issue a license tag, sticker or certificate as evidence of license which shall be displayed by the owner of the business establishment in a conspicuous place. Such evidence of license shall bear the signature of the village president and village clerk. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 3) 
Sec. 22-33.1. - Coin and vending machine stickers. 
    Upon the issuance of a license, the village clerk or designee shall deliver to the licensee one (1) sticker for each coin or vending machine used by the licensee in the conduct of his business, which said sticker shall be attached in a conspicuous place on such machine. 
(Ord. No. 1538-06, § 2, 3-22-2006) 
Sec. 22-33.2. - Form of vending machine stickers. 
    Each such sticker shall have thereon the words, NORRIDGE, ILLINOIS or any abbreviation thereof, the current year, and shall be in such form and color and shall include such other information as the village clerk shall determine. 
(Ord. No. 1538-06, § 2, 3-22-2006) 
Sec. 22-33.3. - Stickers for substitute machines. 
    Additional stickers may be issued by the village clerk for substitute or alternate machines if the licensee applies in writing to the village clerk returning all or a significant portion of the sticker from the machine being withdrawn from service. In the event that the sticker from the machine being withdrawn from service is not returned to the village, the licensee must provide a written verification to the village clerk that the machine being taken out of service has been withdrawn from the village and will not be returned to service within the village. In this event, a substitute sticker may be purchased for one-half the cost of the original sticker for the remainder of the license year. 
(Ord. No. 1538-06, § 2, 3-22-2006) 
Sec. 22-34. - Grounds for denying. 
    No license for the operation of the business establishment in the village shall be issued if one or more of the following conditions are determined by the village clerk, or such other officer as he may designate, to exist: 
1.  The building or premises of the business establishment does not comply with the provisions and terms of the building code, zoning ordinance, fire regulations, health regulations, any ordinances and regulations of the village. 
2.  The building or premises of the business establishment are in a condition of being unsanitary or unsafe so as to endanger the public safety, health or welfare. 
3.  The owner of the business establishment or the legal entity comprising the business establishment is indebted to the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 4) 
Sec. 22-35. - Appeal from denial; hearing. 
A.  If an application for a license is refused or denied by the village clerk, or his duly authorized agent, the applicant therefor may appeal to the village president and board of trustees and shall be entitled to a hearing upon the refusal or denial. 
B.  The president and board of trustees shall conduct such hearing within 30 days after such appeal shall have been made; and shall give notice to the appellant and clerk no less than ten days before such date. 
C.  If upon such hearing the president and board of trustees is of the opinion that such license should be issued, it shall so instruct the village clerk, who shall issue such license. 
D.  If such license is denied upon the hearing, the applicant may refile his application with a statement under oath that the causes for the initial refusal or denial have been corrected and that all the provisions of the state law and the sections of this Code and ordinances of this village have been complied with. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 5) 
Sec. 22-36. - Limited to one business location or establishment. 
    No license for the operation of a business establishment in the village shall be construed by any person to permit the operation of a business establishment in more than one location. For the purpose of this chapter, one location shall be construed to mean that: 
1.  All buildings containing the principal or accessory uses are connected or on the same lot or parcel; and 
2.  Are operated and managed by the same person or owner, and constitute a business establishment with the same classification. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 6) 
Sec. 22-37. - Inspection and enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the village clerk to administer and enforce the terms and provisions of this chapter and to make or cause to be made such inspection of the buildings or premises as may be necessary to accomplish such administration or enforcement. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 7) 
Sec. 22-38. - Change of location. 
    The location of any licensed business or occupation may be changed, provided that ten days' notice of such change is given to the village clerk, in the absence of any provision to the contrary; provided, however, that all requirements of this Code and ordinances are complied with. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 8) 
Sec. 22-39. - Suspension or revocation authorized. 
    Any license issued by the village may be summarily suspended for a period not to exceed 30 days by an employee of the village when the license holder fails to cooperate with the village in an inspection of the business premises or audit of the business's compliance with the laws, rules and regulations applicable to such business. Any license issued by the village may be suspended or revoked by the president and board of trustees upon the violation, by the licensee or his agents or employees, of any provision of this Code or of the state law applicable to the business, trade or occupation covered by such license. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 9; Ord. No. 1804-14, § 2, 7-23-2014) 
Sec. 22-40. - Appeal; hearing on revocation or suspension. 
A.  Upon suspension or revocation of a license, the licensee may appeal to the village president and board of trustees, and shall be entitled to a hearing thereon. 
B.  The president and board of trustees shall conduct such hearing within 30 days after such appeal shall have been made; and shall give notice to the such licensee and interested officers and employees of the village no less than ten days prior to the date of such hearing. 
C.  If upon such hearing the president and board of trustees is of the opinion that such license should be reinstated, they shall do so. 
D.  If the president and board of trustees find that such suspension or revocation was justified, they shall so rule. 
(Code 1972, ch. 7, art. 1, § 10) 
Secs. 22-41-22-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADVERTISING BENCHES[3]
