ARTICLE VIII. - WEAPONS DEALERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note-

Sec. 22-361. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases as used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air rifle means and includes any pneumatic gun, air gun, air pistol, spring gun, spring pistol, BB gun, paintball gun, pellet gun or any similar device which uses a spring, pneumatic device, compressed air or compressed gas to impel a pellet constructed of hard plastic, steel, lead or other hard materials with a force that reasonably is expected to cause bodily harm. Paintball guns are defined separately herein. 
    Ammunition means any self-contained cartridge or shotgun shell, by whatever name known, which is designed to be used or adaptable to use in a firearm; excluding, however: 
1.  Any ammunition exclusively designed for use with a device used exclusively for signaling or safety and required by the United States Coast Guard or the Interstate Commerce Commission; 
2.  Any ammunition designed exclusively for use with a stud or rivet driver or other similar industrial ammunition. 
    Code means the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002, as may be amended from time to time. 
    Firearm means any device, by whatever name known, which is designed or may be readily converted to expel a projectile or projectiles by the action of an explosive or propellant, or by an expansion or escape of gas generated by the process of combustion or ignition, or the component parts of the foregoing, or any combination of component parts either designed or intended for use in converting any device into a firearm as described herein. The definition of firearm excludes: 
1.  Any safety device used exclusively for signaling or safety and required or recommended by the U.S. Coast Guard; 
2.  Any device used exclusively for the firing of stud cartridges, explosive rivets or similar construction or industrial ammunition; 
3.  Model rockets designed to propel a model vehicle in a vertical direction; 
4.  Any air rifle, pneumatic gun, spring gun, paintball gun or BB gun which either expels a single globular projectile not exceeding .18 inch in diameter and which has a maximum muzzle velocity of less than 700 feet per second or breakable paint balls containing washable marking colors. 
    Licensee means a person granted a license as a weapons dealer by the village pursuant to the Code. 
    Paintball gun means any air gun, air pistol or similar device that is designed and intended to use compressed air or gas to discharge a globular projectile filled with paint or similar marking liquid, or another liquid or substance. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, company, limited liability company, association, firm, partnership, club, society, or joint stock company. 
    Weapons dealer means any person, including any person who is a pawnbroker, who: 
1.  Sells, rents, or transfers firearms or their component parts; 
2.  Engages in the business of manufacturing firearms or their component parts for remuneration; 
3.  Sells or transfers ammunition at wholesale or retail; 
4.  Engages in the business of repairing firearms or making or fitting special barrels, trigger mechanisms, stocks, or grips for firearms for remuneration; or 
5.  Sells, loans, rents, exchanges, gives away, or otherwise transfers for consideration: 
A.  Any dagger, stiletto, billy, derringer, bowie knife, dirk, stun gun, or taser, as defined in section 24-1 of the Illinois Criminal Code, 720 ILCS 5/24-1 (collectively, deadly weapons), as may be amended from time to time, or their component parts; or 
B.  Any other deadly weapon which can be carried or concealed on the person; or 
C.  Any firearm or ammunition as those terms are defined in chapter 22, section 22-361 of the Code as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-362. - Weapons dealers prohibited near sensitive places. 
    No weapons dealer may be located on property within 500 feet, measured from property line to property line, of any: a) public or private nursery, elementary, or secondary school; b) nonresidential childcare facility; or c) public park, playground, playing field, or other recreational area. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-363. - License. 
A.  Required. No person may engage in the business of a weapons dealer as set forth in this article within the corporate limits of the village, without first having secured from the village a weapons dealer license. 
B.  Application. 
1.  An application for a weapons dealer license shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to applications for licenses and this article. 
2.  All applications shall be made on the forms provided by the village and shall include, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  The full name and address of the applicant, or, if a corporation, the name and address thereof and the names of its principal officers and their residence addresses, or, if a partnership or unincorporated association, the name and address thereof and the names and residence addresses of each partner or member thereof; if a limited liability company, the names and residence addresses of each member of the limited liability company. 
b.  The location of the weapons dealer establishment at which the sale of dangerous weapons, firearms, and/or ammunition is proposed. 
c.  Evidence that the applicant has a current and valid firearms license issued by the United States Department of Treasury, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, along with the following information concerning the license: 
i.  The federal firearms license number; 
ii.  The class of such license; and 
iii.  The expiration date of such license. 
d.  A certification that no employee of the applicant actually involved in the sale or handling of the dangerous weapons, firearms, and/or ammunition has been convicted of a felony. 
e.  A sworn statement that the applicant will abide by and comply with the local, state, and federal laws associated with the sale of firearms and deadly weapons. 
C.  Fee. The fee for a weapons dealer license shall be as established by the fee ordinance in chapter 22 of the Code. 
D.  License term. The term of a license issued pursuant to this article shall be for one year, subject to revocation as provided in chapter 22 of the Code. 
E.  Transfer restrictions. A weapons dealer license shall be purely a personal privilege and shall expire at the end of the standard license term occurring next after issuance unless sooner revoked. It shall not constitute property, shall not be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, and shall not be alienable or voluntarily or involuntarily transferable. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-364. - Conditions for issuance and maintenance of license. 
    A weapons dealer license shall not be issued to, or maintained by, a licensee unless the following conditions are met: 
A.  Qualifications. The licensee and all employees actually involved in the sale or handling of any inventory specified in this article herein must be (i) at least 21 years of age, (ii) certified by the village chief of police or his or her designee, as being reasonably knowledgeable about the use and operation of such weapons, and (iii) have successfully passed a criminal background investigation, and any other applicable requirements of the United States, the State of Illinois, village, and any other jurisdiction having authority over the premises where the licensee is conducting a weapons dealer business. 
B.  Storage of inventory. All inventory subject to this article shall be stored, maintained, and displayed in locked cases at all times. 
C.  Separate register. A separate register shall be provided and used for all transactions related to the inventory subject to this article. 
D.  Certification required; FOID requirements. The licensee shall require the purchaser of each firearm or ammunition to sign a statement certifying that the purchaser is familiar with, and reasonably knowledgeable about, the use and operation of such firearms and ammunition and is authorized to possess such firearms and ammunition as set forth in state and federal law, as may be amended from time to time. 
E.  Inspections. The licensee shall permit the village to inspect, during regular business hours, all records relating to the sale of firearms required to be maintained pursuant to the Federal Firearms Act, the Federal Gun Control Act, the State of Illinois, and any rules prescribed by the Department of Treasury, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco Firearms and Explosives. 
F.  Alarm system. The licensee shall maintain an operating 24-hour burglar and fire alarm system on the licensed premises, and the alarm must be registered with the village police department. 
G.  Zoning. A licensee hereunder may locate its business as a special use in the village's B-2, B-3, B-5, or C Zoning Districts, subject to the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the Village of Norridge, as amended. 
H.  No expansion. A licensee may not expand its operation beyond boundaries of the premises described in the license application. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-365. - Report of sale. 
    Every weapons dealer licensed pursuant to this article shall make out and deliver to the village chief of police every day before the hours of 12:00 noon, a legible and correct report of every sale or gift made under authority of such license during the preceding 24 hours, which report shall contain the date of such sale or gift, the name of the purchaser or donee with his address and age, his nationality and citizenship, the number, kind, description, and price of such weapon, the number of the purchaser's permit and the purpose given by such person for the purchase of such weapon, which report shall be substantially in the following form: 
Number of permit ..... 
Number of weapon ..... 
Name of purchaser ..... 
Address of purchaser ..... 
Citizen or alien ..... 
If alien, name of country subject of ..... 
Age of purchaser ..... 
Kind or description of weapon ..... 
For what purpose purchased ..... 
Price ..... 
If no such sale has been made during the preceding 24 hours, then it shall not be necessary to file the report for such period. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-366. - Denial; revocation. 
    A license issued pursuant to this article may be temporarily suspended, revoked, or an application for issuance or renewal of a license may be refused by the village, if: 
A.  The application for the license contains any false, fraudulent, or misleading material statement; 
B.  The license applicant has made any false, fraudulent, or misleading material statement, or has been convicted of perpetrating a fraud upon any person, or has committed a felony; 
C.  The license applicant has conducted any business in an unlawful manner or in such manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public; or 
D.  The licensee has violated any of the provisions of this article or of any other code, ordinance, resolution, rule, or regulation of the village. 
    An applicant or licensee aggrieved by the action of the village in refusing to issue any license, or in suspending or revoking any license already issued, shall have the right to appeal such decision in accordance with, and as provided by, section 22-367 below. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-367. - Administrative appeal. 
A.  Procedure. If any license issued hereunder shall have been suspended or revoked, the licensee shall be notified in writing of the reasons for such denial, suspension, or revocation by the village. Within ten days thereafter, the licensee may request an administrative hearing pursuant to chapter 2, article VII of the Code. 
B.  Revocation. If the hearing officer is satisfied that such applicant or licensee has violated any provisions of this article, he or she may revoke the license of such person for the selling of such weapons. In such a case, the money paid for such license shall be forfeited to the village, and no other such license shall be issued to such licensee. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-368. - Construction. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed or applied to necessarily require or excuse noncompliance with any provision of the laws of the State of Illinois or to the laws of the United States. This article and the penalties prescribed for violation hereof, shall not supersede, but shall supplement all statutes of the State of Illinois or of the United States in which similar conduct may be prohibited or regulated. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-369. - Severability. 
    If any provisions of this article or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the remainder of this article and the applicability of such provisions to other persons not similarly situated or to other circumstances shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Sec. 22-370. - Preemption. 
    This article shall preempt all Cook County licensing or other regulatory schemes for weapons dealers. As provided in Article VII, Section 6(c) of the State of Illinois Constitution of 1970, if a county ordinance conflicts with an ordinance of a municipality, the municipality's ordinance shall prevail within its jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1816-14, § 2, 12-10-2014) 
Secs. 22-371-22-399. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - FARMERS MARKETS 

Sec. 22-400. - License required. 
    No person shall vend or sell without first having obtained a Norridge Farmers Market vendor license. No license shall be issued to: (1) any person or entity who or which is indebted to the Village of Norridge or (2) who has been convicted of a felony. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-401. - Authorized sales. 
    A farmers market vendor licensee may vend only agricultural produce, eggs, meat and crafts grown, raised or manufactured within 150 miles of Norridge. Reselling of other's merchandise is not allowed. Any person or entity with a current business license from the Village of Norridge shall be entitled to apply for a farmer's market vendor license. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-402. - License, fees. 
    A seasonal farmer's market license shall be in effect twice per month on a schedule set annually by the board of trustees by resolution. The fee for the license shall be as provided for in chapter 38. A daily farmer's market license shall be in effect for one day. The fee for the license shall be as provided for in chapter 38. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-403. - Application and renewal. 
    In addition to information required in the general licensing provisions of this chapter, the application for a farmer's market vendors license shall include: 
A.  A signed statement that the applicant shall hold harmless the village, its officers and employees and shall indemnify the village, its officers and employees for any claims for damage to property or injury to persons which may be occasioned by any activity carried on under the terms of the license. 
B.  A certificate of motor vehicle liability insurance that will protect against all claims for damage to property or bodily injury, including death. Such insurance shall provide coverage of not less than $100,000.00 for bodily injury for each person, $300,000.00 for each occurrence and not less than $50,000.00 for property damage per occurrence and shall further provide that the policy shall not be terminated, modified or canceled prior to the expiration of the license without 30 days' written notice to the Norridge Village Clerk. 
C.  A certificate of general commercial liability insurance in an amount no less than $1,000.000.00 per incident. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-404. - Issuance of license. 
A.  The approving authority shall be the business license department supervisor. 
B.  In addition to the requirements of the general licensing provisions, each applicant shall provide the village with a certificate of the insurance coverages required in section 22-403 of this chapter naming the village as an additional insured. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-405. - Number of licenses. 
    The number of vendor licenses issued shall be limited each year depending on space available. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-406. - Spacing of farmers market stands. 
    Farmers market vendor stands shall be assigned a specific location. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-407. - Vendor stands. 
A.  Pushcarts and vendor stands shall conform to design specifications prepared by the village engineer considering pedestrian safety, consumer safety, fire safety, surface load requirements on the pavement to protect paving materials and shall not exceed ten feet in length, ten feet in width, and 11 feet in height. 
B.  No overnight storage shall be permitted. 
C.  The vendor stand shall be portable and shall be removed by 9:30 p.m. each market day. 
D.  No canopy, awning, tent top, or other vertical extension of the vendor stand shall be allowed unless it is a fixture of the vendor stand and does not require attachment to any other object. 
E.  Hours of operation; loading. 
1.  On market days, vendors may operate between the hours of 3:00 p.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
2.  A vendor shall operate a minimum of three hours per day for each sale day that the license is in effect. 
3.  Loading and unloading shall be prohibited prior to noon and during the hours of 3:00 p.m. to 8:00 p.m. on market days. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-408. - Health regulations. 
    All food held, offered for sale, or sold by licensees shall be subject to and comply with all applicable requirements for such food contained in this Code and the rules and regulations promulgated hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-409. - Restrictions. 
A.  No vendor shall sell to any person in a motor vehicle or who is standing in a street, highway or roadway. 
B.  No vendor shall sell from a location other than that designated on the license. 
C.  No vendor shall leave his or her stand unattended. 
D.  No vendor shall utilize extension cords that are located outside of the vendor stand in areas used as pedestrian walkways, or extension cords that are not approved by the village. 
E.  No heat-generating devices shall be located on the stand without the specific approval of the village. 
F.  No advertising, except the posting of prices shall be permitted on any vendor stand, except to identify the name of the product and the vendor. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Sec. 22-410. - Exemptions. 
A.  Any vendor authorized by and sharing receipts with a government agency, religious organization, or not-for-profit corporation may vend at the farmers market during the sponsoring of a special event without procuring a farmers market vendors license. 
B.  All other applicable licenses and permits required by this Code must be obtained by all persons engaging in vending operations described above. 
(Ord. No. 1715-11, § 2, 7-27-2011) 
Chapter 26 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; law enforcement, ch. 58. 
State Law reference- Emergency Management Agency Act, 20 ILCS 3305/1 et seq. 

Sec. 26-1. - Emergency proclamations by president. 
A.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Civil emergency means: 
1.  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three or more persons acting together without authority of law. 
2.  Any natural disaster or manmade calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village, except for officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to such civil emergency. 
B.  Declaration. Whenever an emergency exists, the president shall declare the existence by means of a written declaration, under oath, setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency. 
C.  General curfew ordered; area of applicability. After proclamation of a civil emergency by the president, he may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village, or to the village as a whole, as he deems advisable and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the public safety and welfare. 
D.  Additional orders. After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the president of the village may also, in the interest of public safety and welfare, make any or all the following orders: 
1.  Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and private clubs or portions of such places wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted. 
2.  Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any wholesaler or retailer. 
3.  Order the discontinuance of the selling, distributing or giving away of gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle. 
4.  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
5.  Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
E.  Effective period of proclamation; extension. The proclamation authorized in this section shall be effective for a period of 48 hours unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the president indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists; provided, however, that in no event shall a proclamation be effective after the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the corporate authorities after the emergency is declared. The president shall have the power to reproclaim the existence of a civil emergency at the end of each 48-hour period during the time the civil emergency exists. 
F.  Notice. Upon issuing the proclamation authorized in this section, the chief of police shall notify the news media situated within the village and shall cause three copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the following places within the village: the village hall, the Norwood Park fire station and the Ridgewood High School. 
G.  Violation an offense. Any person violating the provisions of this section, or an executive order issued pursuant thereto, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1972, ch. 16, §§ 1-7) 
State Law reference- Authority to grant emergency powers to president, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2.1, 5/11-1-6.

Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Storing or parking damaged, dismantled or junked vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful to store or park partially dismantled or damaged vehicles or junked vehicles in any open lot, street or alley or premises open to the public view. 
(Code 1972, ch. 18, art. 2, § 46) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94.

ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to define, prevent and abate nuisances, 65 ILCS 5/11-60-2. 

Sec. 34-31. - Enumeration. 
A.  Declaration. The following are declared nuisances for any person within the limits of the village: 
1.  Offensive smells. To so negligently conduct any business or to use premises as to create such an offensive smell as may taint the air and render it unwholesome or disagreeable in the neighborhood. 
2.  Allowing carcass to remain. To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or vegetable matter, slops, swill, suds, garbage, filth, stable drippings or offal, or noisome substance of any kind, to be collected or deposited or to remain in any place in the village to the prejudice of others. 
3.  Throwing offal in watercourse. To throw or deposit, or cause to be thrown or deposited, any offal or other offensive matter, or the carcass of any animal, in any watercourse, pond, spring or well within the limits of the village. 
4.  Nightsoil. To deposit any nightsoil, dead animal or other filthy, offensive or noisome substance upon any lot, street, alley, highway, park or other place. 
5.  Corrupting drinking water. To corrupt or render unwholesome, or to injure the water of any drinking hydrant, spring, stream, pond or lake to the injury and prejudice of others. 
6.  Suffering grass, leaves and other combustible matter to accumulate. To cause or suffer grass, leaves, underbrush or other combustible matter to be collected, deposited or to remain on his premises in such quantities and in such condition as to materially increase the danger to property of others from forest or other fires. 
7.  Obstructing highways. To obstruct or to encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets, alleys, sidewalks and commons. 
8.  Maintaining unwholesome business. To establish, maintain or carry on any offensive or unwholesome business within the limits of the village or within one mile of its limits. 
9.  Permitting slops to remain on premises; time limit. For any person to permit any slops, swill, garbage, stable drippings, offal, filth, refuse, animal or vegetable matter, which is liable to become putrid or offensive or injurious to health, to remain on any premises used or occupied by him, for a longer period than 12 hours at a time. 
10.  Keeping premises in filthy condition. To keep or to suffer to be kept in a foul, offensive, nauseous or filthy condition, any chicken coop, cow house, stable, collar, vault, drain, privy, sewer or sink upon any premises belonging to or occupied by him, or any railroad car, building, yard, grounds and premises belonging to or occupied by him. 
11.  Offensive animal pens. To own, use or keep any yard, pen, place, railroad car or premises, in or upon which cattle or other animals shall be confined or kept, so as to be offensive to those residing in the vicinity, or any annoyance to others. 
12.  Privy. To erect or maintain any privy within the village. 
13.  Slaughtering. To slaughter or kill any animal. 
14.  To obstruct any watercourse, ravine or gutter. To obstruct any watercourse, ravine or gutter so as to cause water to stagnate therein, or to permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any premises to the prejudice of others. 
15.  Noxious growths. To permit the growth upon any premises of any noxious weeds, such as jimpson, burdock, ragweed, thistles, cockleburrs and like weeds. 
16.  Spitting in public places. To spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk, street or other public place, or floor or walk of any public vehicle or hall or other public building. 
17.  Committing common law or state law nuisances. To commit any offense which is a nuisance according to the common law of the land, or made such by the statutes of the state. 
18.  Growth of poplar or cottonwood trees or willow trees. To permit the growth upon any premises of any poplar or cottonwood trees or willow trees. A poplar tree is hereby defined as any of a genus of slender quick-growing salicaceous trees, also known as populus. A cottonwood tree is hereby defined as a tree of the poplar group with a cottony comma investing the seeds, also known as populus balsamifera. 
19.  Dense smoke. To allow or permit any dense smoke to come or be emitted from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or other agency within the limits of the village is declared to be a nuisance, and may be summarily abated by the president or health committee, or by any one whom they, or either of them, may authorize for such purpose. Such abatement may be in addition to the fine provided for violation of this section. 
20.  Noise. To conduct any operations (including property and grounds maintenance) between the hour of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, or 10:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. on Sundays or holidays; including but not limited to the operation of any steam shovels, lawn mowers, pneumatic hammers, steam or electric hoists or other apparatus the use of which is attended with loud or unusual noise, in any block in which more than half of the buildings on either side of the street are used exclusively for residence purposes. This subsection does not prohibit emergency repairs necessary to protect life or property. 
21.  Noisy or dangerous business use of buildings. To own or possess, be in charge or control of any building or premises and use the same, or permit the use of the same, or rent the same to be used for any business employment, or for any purpose of pleasure or recreation, if such use shall, from its noise or boisterous nature, disturb or destroy the peace of the neighborhood in which such building or premises are situated, or be dangerous or detrimental to health. 
22.  Vendors. To violate subsection B. of this section. 
23.  Accumulation of water in ponds. 
a.  The allowing of water to accumulate and remain in a pond, either wholly or partly within the limits of any private property for a period of more than ten consecutive days. Such nuisance shall be abated. 
b.  For the purposes of this subsection, the term "pond" shall be considered to mean any exposed surface of water not less than 100 square feet in area which has accumulated either by natural or artificial means, in any depression or connected series of depressions or excavations, whether existing naturally or created artificially. 
24.  Unsightly yards. To permit or maintain any unsightly yard or premises where there is an accumulation or deposit of any vehicle, equipment, material of any nature, waste or earth. 
25.  Violation of building and fire prevention codes, zoning ordinance and other premises nuisance violations. To violate the building code, fire prevention code or zoning ordinance, or to maintain premises in a condition declared by the president of the village to be a nuisance. 
26.  Junk, wrecked or disabled vehicles. To maintain an unsightly yard or area where junk, wrecked or disabled automobiles, trucks or equipment, or other such matter is allowed to accumulate. 
27.  Creation of harborage for rodents, vermin or other nuisance. To collect, deposit or suffer debris or junk in such quantities and in such condition as to increase breeding and refuge for rodents, vermin or any undesirable nuisance. 
28.  Garbage cans and containers. To cause or suffer garbage cans or containers to be placed or to remain on parkways, walks, driveways or front yards on any day before 6:00 p.m. on the day preceding public garbage pickup, or after 7:00 p.m. on the day public garbage pickup is made. 
29.  Burning of garbage or other refuse. To burn garbage or any other offensive refuse within the limits of the village. 
30.  Littering. To leave or scatter wastepaper, paper containers for foodstuffs, bills, posters, lithographs, advertising matter, refuse, sweepings or material of like substance, in or upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public grounds of the village. 
31.  Phonographs, radios, loudspeakers, etc. To operate or play, or cause to be operated or played, any phonograph, gramophone, radio set, wireless set, loudspeaker or other device or instrument whereby sound is amplified during the hours from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. of the following day, in such manner or with such volume that the sound caused thereby is audible to human beings beyond a distance of 400 feet from such phonograph, gramophone, radio set, wireless set or other device or instrument, and beyond the premises whereon the same is operated or played. 
32.  Riding of horses in public places. To ride horses on the streets, sidewalks, alleys or parkways of the village. 
33.  Keeping animals other than domestic pets. To own, keep or allow to be at large any bees, goats, sheep, hogs, cattle or fowl within the village. The term "fowl" shall include chickens, turkeys, geese, ducks or pigeons. 
34.  Storage of vehicles, boats, campers and trailers. To store any vehicle, boat, camper, house trailer or trailer on any driveway, front yard, side yard or back yard in a residential area. For the purpose of this subsection, the term "store" shall be considered to mean parking or letting stand any vehicle, boat, camper, house trailer or trailer for a period of more than 24 hours. 
35.  Depositing leaves, grass or snow. To deposit, by any means, leaves, grass or snow onto the public streets or alleys. 
B.  Vendors; prohibited acts; penalty for violation. 
1.  The custom among merchants dealing in ice cream, ices, soda waters and other soft drinks, of delivering at the curb, in the street, or upon the sidewalks or roadways, their merchandise in paper cups, cartons, plates or other containers, has become a nuisance and a menace to the pedestrians and persons traveling on the roadways by reason of the depositing of such cups, cartons, plates or other containers on the sidewalks and streets. 
2.  No person dealing at retail in ice cream, soda waters and other soft drinks or merchandise of like character shall deliver the same upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public ways of this village. 
3.  No person shall throw or drop such cup, plate or container upon a sidewalk, crosswalk, roadway or any part of any public street. 
4.  The sale or disposition by any person of food, beverage, dairy products, ice cream or any of its kindred products, in paper, cardboard or any other container known by such person to be intended to be consumed by the buyer on the sidewalks, alleys or at or near the place of business where such food or beverages are sold or dispensed is a danger to the health and sanitation of the community. 
5.  No such dealer shall deliver any such goods to a person known to be a runner, or person employed to carry such goods from the place of business to persons on the sidewalk, curb or street. No such runner shall deliver any such merchandise on the streets, sidewalks or alleys of the village. 
6.  Any dealer in ice cream, ices, soda waters or other soft drinks or merchandise of like character who shall violate any of the provisions of this subsection shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $750.00, and shall be subject, upon a second offense, to have his license as such a dealer revoked by the president. Any person throwing or dropping such a cup, plate or container on the street shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $750.00. Any person acting as such runner as prohibited in this subsection shall be subject to a like fine, upon conviction. 
(Code 1972, ch. 13, § 1; Ord. No. 1330-01, § 1, 2-14-2001; Ord. No. 1367-01, § 1, 11-14-2001) 
Sec. 34-32. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Whoever violates any clause, section or provision of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $1,000.00, and if the offender shall fail to abate such nuisance, then any offender shall be held to a penalty of not less than $25.00 nor more than $1,000.00 for each and every day such nuisance shall remain in existence after notice to abate such nuisance. 
(Code 1972, ch. 13, § 2) 
Sec. 34-33. - President may abate. 
    Whenever any nuisance exists or shall be found on any premises within the village, whether such nuisance is one specifically recognized by ordinance or not, the president of the village is authorized, in his discretion, to cause the nuisance to be summarily abated in such manner as he may direct, and at the expense of the party permitting or maintaining such nuisance. 
(Code 1972, ch. 13, § 3) 
Secs. 34-34-34-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AIR POLLUTION[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Air pollution, 415 ILCS 5/8 et seq.; local air contamination control ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-19.1-11. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air pollution means the escape or emission from stacks, chimneys, exhaust, vents, ducts, openings, buildings, structures, premises, open fires, vehicles, processes, or any source whatsoever of any smoke, soot, fly ash, dust, dirt, cinders, ashes, fumes, oxides, gases, vapors, odors, toxic or radioactive substances, wastes, particulate, solid, liquid or gaseous matter or any other material in such a manner or in such quantity, or concentration, as to cause or which might tend to cause injury, annoyance, detriment or damage to any person, or which endangers or might tend to endanger the health, comfort, safety or welfare of any person, or as to cause, or which might tend to cause injury or damage to business or property. 
    Ashes means cinders, fly ash or any other solid material resulting from combustion, and may include unburned combustibles. 
    Construction means installation, alteration, construction, addition or repair of any building, fuel-burning, combustion and process equipment or devices, furnaces, and smoke prevention and air pollution control devices, and without regard to whether a building permit is required in connection therewith. 
    Dust means particulate matter released into the air by natural forces, or by any fuel burning, combustion or process equipment, or device, or by construction work, or by mechanical or industrial processes, such as crushing, grinding, milling, drilling, demolishing, shoveling, bagging, sweeping, covering, conveying, transferring, transporting and the like. 
    Fly ash means particulate matter capable of being gasborne and consisting essentially of fused ash and or burned or unburned material. 
    Fuel means any form of combustible matter: solid, liquid, vapor or gas. 
    Fuel-burning, combustion, or process equipment or device means any furnace incinerator, fuel-burning equipment, refuse-burning equipment, boiler, apparatus, device, mechanism, fly ash collector, electrostatic precipitator, smoke arresting or prevention equipment, stack, chimney, breeching or structure used for the burning of fuel or other combustible material, or for the emission of products of combustion, or used in connection with any process which generates heat and may emit products of combustion; and shall include process furnaces, such as heat treating furnaces, byproduct cake plants, core-baking ovens, mixing kettles, cupolas, blast furnaces, open hearth furnaces, heating and reheating furnaces, puddling furnaces, sintering plants, bessemer converters, electric steel furnaces, ferrous foundries, nonferrous foundries, kilns, stills, dryers, roasters, and equipment used in connection therewith, and all other methods or forms of manufacturing, chemical, metallurgical or mechanical processing which may emit smoke or particulate liquid, gaseous or other matter. 
    Fumes means gases, vapors or particulate matter that are of such character as to cause atmospheric pollution. 
    Garbage incinerator means any device intended for, or used for, the destruction of garbage or other combustible refuse or waste materials by burning. 
    Internal combustion engine means an engine in which combustion of gaseous, liquid or pulverized solid fuel takes place within one or more cylinders. 
    Noxious matter or materials means matter or material which is capable of causing detrimental effects upon the physical or economic well-being of individuals. 
    Odorous matter means any matter or material that yields an odor which is offensive in any way. 
    Open fire means any fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly into the open air without passing through a stack or chimney or designated or approved aboveground fireplace. 
    Particulate matter means material other than gases or water which is suspended in or discharged into the atmosphere in a finely divided form as a liquid or a solid. 
    Process equipment and devices means all equipment or devices used in any commercial or industrial operation, and which is capable of causing air pollution. 
    Ringelmann chart means that which is described in the United States Bureau of Mines, Information Circular 6888, and on which are illustrated graded shades of gray for use in estimating the light obscuring capacity of smoke. 
    Ringelmann number means the number appearing on the Ringelmann chart describing the density or equivalent capacity of smoke emission. Where the density or opacity of smoke as observed falls between two consecutive Ringelmann numbers, the lower Ringelmann number shall be considered the density or opacity of the smoke observed. 
    Smoke means gaseous products, particulate matter of colloidal dimensions, and entrained particulate matter of larger than colloidal dimensions which are the result of combustion. 
    Smoke unit means the number obtained when the opacity of smoke or particulate matter expressed in Ringelmann number is multiplied by the time of emission expressed in minutes. For the purpose of this calculation, a Ringelmann opacity reading shall be made at least once per minute during the period of observation. Each is then multiplied by the time in minutes during which it was observed. The various products are then added together to give the total number of smoke units observed during the entire period of observation. 
    Soot means and consists of agglomerated particles composed essentially of carbonaceous material. 
    Stack means a vertical conduit attached to a permanent structure. 
    Toxic matter or materials means materials which are capable of causing injury to living organisms by chemical means when present in relatively small amounts. 
    Vehicle means a self-propelled mechanism, such as a truck, machine, tractor, roller, derrick, crane, trencher, portable hoisting engine or automobile, or any conveyance used for carrying persons or things. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 1, § 1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-62. - Article provisions not to be deemed consent, license or permit. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be deemed to be a consent, license or permit to locate, construct or maintain any building, structure or facility or to carry on any trade, industry, occupation or activity. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 2, § 2) 
Sec. 34-63. - Adoption of state environmental provisions. 
    There is adopted by reference the Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.) and all rules and regulations pursuant to the same. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 1) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq., 50 ILCS 220/0.01 et seq. 
Sec. 34-64. - Instruction of operators of combustion equipment and devices. 
    It shall be the duty of owners or agents of any burning combustion equipment device, or process equipment device, to instruct, or cause to be instructed, the operators, operating crews, enginemen, firemen, janitors or any other person operating such combustion equipment or device. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 6) 
Sec. 34-65. - Open fires. 
A.  The open burning of any paper, garbage, refuse, automobiles, waste, leaves, clippings or other combustible material is prohibited, with the exception of the following: 
1.  Fires set by a public official in the performance of an official duty. 
2.  Fires used for private or public recreational purposes. 
3.  Fires in outdoor fireplaces designed for cooking food. 
B.  General restrictions. No such fire referred to in subsections A.2. and A.3. of this section shall be used as an incinerator, or be permitted to become a nuisance or a source of annoyance or discomfort to any person by reason of the emission of smoke, fumes, fly ash, dust or soot as elsewhere prohibited by this article. 
C.  Specific restrictions. 
1.  Private open fires cannot be left unattended. 
2.  Only seasoned wood (wood that is split and dried for at least six months) can be burned. 
3.  No open fires which emit smoke. 
4.  A connected garden hose or other means to extinguish the fire must be readily available. 
5.  The use of flammable or combustible liquids is not permitted. 
6.  Police and fire department officers are authorized to require that a private open fire be immediately extinguished and discontinued if it is determined that the fire is not in compliance with the above rules, the smoke is offensive to nearby neighbors, or the burning is determined to constitute a hazardous condition. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 2(1); Ord. No. 1852-16, § 2, 5-25-2016) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
Sec. 34-66. - Smoke, windborne and particulate matter. 
A.  Dust, soot, ashes, dirt, fly ash and other materials susceptible to becoming windborne shall not be handled, loaded, stored, transferred, transported, placed, deposited, thrown, discarded or scattered without reasonable precautions or measures, such as wetting down or covering such materials, having been taken to minimize atmospheric pollution; nor shall any building, structure, or premises, open area, right-of-way, storage pile, yard, drive, path, vessel or vehicle, or construction alteration, excavation, demolition or wrecking operation involving or emitting such material be maintained, performed or undertaken without the taking of such precautions. 
B.  Escape or emission from any source whatsoever of soot, smoke, dust, gas, noxious odor, fly ash, vapor or other air contaminant, or combinations thereof, in such quantity or in such manner as to be annoying to the community, or so as to endanger or be detrimental to the health, safety, comfort, or well-being of its inhabitants, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and is prohibited. 
C.  No person owning or in charge of any fuel-burning combustion or process equipment or device shall cause, permit or allow the emission into the atmosphere from any single such source of particulate matter which averages in excess of 0.35 grains per cubic foot of gas corrected in volume to a temperature of 60 degrees Fahrenheit and a pressure of 30 inches of mercury. 
D.  Any boiler or furnace, other than one used for heating or hot water purposes in a one-family residence, equipped with a pulverized coal burner or spreader stoker shall be equipped with a collector, capable of keeping particulate emission within the limits specified by this article. 
E.  Any cupola, kiln furnace or other equipment, other than that used for heating or hot water purposes in a one-family residence, capable of emitting particles into the atmosphere, shall be equipped with suitable dust collectors, capable of keeping emission of particulate matter within the limits specified in this article. 
F.  A regular inspection and maintenance schedule for all particle collectors which discharge their effluent into the open air shall be set up by the owners or operators of such collectors to ensure that they function properly, and a written record shall be maintained, and shall be made available for inspection by the building commissioner or its representatives, whenever requested. This subsection applies to existing as well as to new equipment. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 2(2)) 
Sec. 34-67. - Combustion products. 
A.  Emission from any source of smoke or particulate matter of an opacity greater than No. 2 on the Ringelmann chart is prohibited at all times, except as specifically provided in this section. 
B.  Emission of smoke or particulate matter of an opacity greater than No. 1 on the Ringelmann chart from domestic installations for heating and hot water in one-family residences is prohibited at all times. 
C.  The emission of more than 15 smoke units per hour from any single source of combustion is prohibited, except that once during any six-hour period, up to 30 additional smoke units may be emitted during the course of blowing soot, or while building a new fire or cleaning a fire. 
D.  Except from domestic installations for heating and hot water in one-family residences, smoke of an opacity equal to Ringelmann No. 3 may be emitted from any single source for up to four minutes once during any six-hour period, but only during the course of building a new fire, cleaning a fire or blowing soot. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 2(3)) 
Sec. 34-68. - Fumes and noxious odors. 
    Escape or emission from any source whatsoever of fumes or odors that are detrimental or injurious to the property, health, safety, comfort or welfare of inhabitants of the community is declared to be a public nuisance and is prohibited. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 2(4)) 
Sec. 34-69. - Motor vehicles. 
    Operation of internal combustion engines which emit visible smoke or visible fumes having an opacity in excess of Ringelmann No. 2 is prohibited. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 2(5)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 34-70. - Radioactive material. 
    Radioactive materials shall not be permitted to escape into the atmosphere in excess of the limits set by the Rules and Regulations of the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission and the state in effect from time to time concerning such material. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 3, § 2(6)) 
Secs. 34-71-34-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 34-91. - Enforcing officer; duties. 
    The administration and enforcement of this article shall be by and under the direction and control of the building commissioner, or his duly authorized representative, whose duties shall be as follows: 
1.  To supervise the execution of all laws, ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to air pollution control as provided in this article. 
2.  To institute necessary proceedings to prosecute violations of this article and to compel the prevention and abatement of air pollution or nuisances arising therefrom. 
3.  To examine and approve the plans of burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device, furnaces and smoke prevention and air pollution control devices installed, constructed, reconstructed, repaired or added to in any building, location or on any premises within the village as provided in this section to ensure that they are in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
4.  To make inspections of newly installed, constructed, reconstructed, repaired or altered burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device, furnaces and smoke prevention and air pollution control devices, and to make annual or periodic inspections to fuel-burning combustion or process equipment or devices within the village as provided in this section, to determine whether such equipment is in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
5.  To investigate complaints of violations of this article and to make inspections and observations of air pollution conditions. 
6.  To serve as an advisor to the village board. 
7.  To issue all permits, certificates, notices or other matters required under the provisions of this article, and to notify all persons concerned, of any decisions he may render, and to provide such persons with an opportunity to be heard as set forth in this section. 
8.  To investigate and make recommendations from time to time to the board with respect to needed additions or revisions to this article, or any ordinance pertaining to air pollution control. 
9.  To do any and all acts which may be necessary for the successful prosecution of the purposes of this article and such other acts as may be specifically enumerated in this section as his duties. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 4) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-161 et seq. 
Sec. 34-92. - Air pollution control board. 
A.  The village board comprised of the president, the village clerk and the trustees is hereby designated as the air pollution board. 
B.  A majority of the air pollution board is vested with the following jurisdiction and authority: 
1.  To decide appeals from any decision, ruling, regulation, determination or other order made by the building commissioner under this article, or failure to act upon request within a reasonable period by the building commissioner in the manner of and subject to the standards set forth in this article. Such decisions on appeal shall be limited to construing the provisions of this article in order to determine whether the building commissioner has correctly interpreted requirements established by such sections. 
2.  To grant applications for extensions of time for compliance upon showing of due diligence on the part of the applicant. To grant variation for any fuel-burning, combustion or process equipment or device, or exemptions or variations from the provisions of this article whenever it is found, upon the presentation of adequate proof that, because of conditions beyond control, compliance with any provisions of this article or other ordinance relating to atmospheric pollution, or with the code of recommended practices, or any rule, regulation, requirement or order of the building commissioner or the failure of the building commissioner to act on any complaint, will result in an arbitrary and unreasonable taking of property or in the practical closing and elimination of any lawful business, occupation or activity, in either case without a sufficient corresponding benefit or advantage to the people in the reduction of atmospheric pollution. In such case, there shall be prescribed other and different requirements not more onerous, applicable to plants or equipment involved. 
3.  To recommend changes to this article to the village board. 
4.  To hear and decide appeals from any final decision, ruling, requirement, rule, regulation or order of the building commissioner taken by any person affected. Such appeal shall be taken within 30 days after receiving notice of such decision, ruling, requirement, rule, regulation or order, by filing with the building commissioner a notice of appeal directed to the air pollution appeal board, specifying the grounds of such appeal and the relief sought. 
C.  The building commissioner shall forthwith furnish to the air pollution board all papers relating to the case. The board shall within ten days after the date of filing the appeal, set a date for the hearing and shall give written notice by mail to the interested parties. The appeal board may, in its discretion, grant continuances. Such an appeal shall act as a stay of the decision, ruling, requirement, rule, regulation or order in question until the air pollution board has taken final action on the appeal. At the hearing, any party may appear in person, or by agent or attorney, and present evidence, both written and oral, pertinent to the question and issues involved, and may examine and cross examine witnesses. The board, after the hearing, shall affirm, modify or reverse the decision, ruling, requirement, rule, regulation or order of the building commissioner, or order him to act. The decision of the air pollution board shall be binding on the building commissioner. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 5) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-421 et seq. 
Sec. 34-93. - Notice of violation. 
    The building commissioner or his representative is hereby authorized to issue notices of violation for the purpose of giving notice to persons allegedly violating any of the provisions of this article or other ordinances relating to air pollution. If at the time of any original inspection or annual inspection, or any other inspection, it is found that any burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device, or premises, is being operated or managed in violation, or is in such a condition or so installed in violation of any requirements provided in this article, the building commissioner shall give notice in writing to any or all persons owning or operating or in charge of such equipment or device or premises, of the defective equipment or device, condition, operation or violation. Such notice may be given by an inspector or other properly trained, authorized agent of the building commissioner by delivering such notice to any person owning, operating or in charge of the equipment or device, or premises involved, or by leaving a copy with a person in charge of such equipment, device or premises, or by mailing a copy directed to the last known address of the person to be notified. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 6) 
Sec. 34-94. - Installation and operation permits. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person to install, erect, construct, reconstruct, alter or add to, or cause to be installed, erected, constructed, reconstructed or altered, or added to, any burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device, or any equipment pertaining thereto, or any stack or chimney connected therewith, within the village, except for domestic heating plants, domestic refuse burning equipment, or to make or cause to be made major repairs on any high pressure boiler furnaces or the brickwork on or about the same, in the village, until an application for installation and operating permits on forms supplied by the building department, including suitable plans and specifications of the burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device, or high pressure boiler, furnace and the structures or buildings used in connection therewith, has been filed in duplicate by the owner, contractor, installer or other person or his agent, in the office of the building commissioner and has been approved as being so designed that the same can be managed and operated to conform to the provisions of this article, and an installation permit issued by him for such installation, erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration or addition. 
B.  The plans and specifications submitted, pursuant to subsection A. of this section, shall be prepared under the direction of, or approved by, a registered professional engineer, registered in the state, and bear his seal. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 7) 
Sec. 34-95. - Certificate of operation. 
A.  Upon finding that any burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device inspected on any original, annual or subsequent inspection had been found to comply with the provisions of this article and after payment of the prescribed fee, the building commissioner shall issue a certificate of operation which shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the equipment or process. The certificate of operation may contain such information and certification as are contained in allowable fuel certificates. 
B.  It shall be unlawful for any person or his agent to use or operate any burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device which is subject to annual inspection, without having an effective certificate of operation therefor. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 8) 
Sec. 34-96. - Fees. 
    Fees for the inspection of plans and issuing installation permits for the installation, erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration of or addition to burning combustion equipment device or process equipment device, or high pressure boiler, furnaces and installation of apparatus or devices for the prevention or arresting of the discharge of air pollutants, except domestic equipment, shall be as listed in section 38-34 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, ch. 15, art. 9) 
Chapter 38 - FINES, PENALTIES AND FEES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 38-1. - Dishonored checks. 
    Any person who issues a check or other draft payable to the village that is not honored upon presentment because the drawer does not have an account with the drawee, because the drawer does not have sufficient funds in his account, or for any other reason, shall be liable to the village in the amount of $20.00 for each check or other draft dishonored. 
(Ord. No. 1427-02, § 2, 11-13-2002) 
Sec. 38-2. - Convenience fee imposed. 
    The village is hereby authorized to enter into agreements with debit or credit card companies to accept debit or credit card payments and to agree to the payment of the charges imposed by those companies. If any of those agreements becomes effective, payments to the village shall be accepted via the debit or credit card process. For each such payment accepted via debit or credit card there shall be imposed a convenience fee imposed of $1.00 or two percent of the payment amount, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 1718-11, § 2, 8-24-2011) 
Sec. 38-2.804. - FOIA. 
    Compliance charges for commercial requests permitted by the FOIA shall be set at the maximum statutory rate allowed in the FOIA (5 ILCS 140/6). If no statutory maximum rate exists, the rates shall be as follows: 
(1)  No fees shall be charged for the first 50 pages of black and white, letter or legal sized copies. Additional pages of black and white, letter or legal sized copies shall be provided at $0.15 per page. 
(2)  Copies of pages larger than legal sized or in color shall be provided at $0.25 per page if copied internally. If the documents are not able to be reproduced by the village, the fee will be the actual cost for producing the records. 
(3)  Commercial requests as described in the FOIA at 5 ILCS 140/6(f) shall be billed at the foregoing page rates plus: an hourly fee for time spent by village personnel in searching for and retrieving records plus any fees and costs incurred in the retrieval or transport of responsive records. Time spent by village personnel shall be reimbursed at $10.00 per hour. Provided, however, the first eight hours of time spent by village personnel searching for and retrieving the requested records shall not incur any fee. If fees are sought under this subsection, the village will provide the requester of an accounting of all fees, costs, and personnel hours incurred in connection with the request for records. 
(Ord. No. 1721-11, § 3, 10-26-2011) 
Secs. 38-3-38-9. - Reserved.

Sec. 38-18. - Buildings. 
A.  Building permits and fees. 
Types of permits Requirements (administrative fee of $25.00 due on each residential permit application and $50.00 on all other permit applications) Contractor's permit: Application completed in full. Valid trade license (plumber, electrician, roofer). Copy of business liability insurance. License and permit bond for concrete and roofing contractors in the amount of $25,000.00. B.  Permits; permit fees; inspection fees. Unless otherwise noted herein, all fees set forth in this section include inspection fees. Except as specifically noted below, there will be an administrative fee of $25.00 due on all residential permit applications and $50.00 on all other permit applications.

a.  Permits are required for the following:

b.  Construction permit fees for new construction, additions and remodeling are $1.25 per square foot except for unfinished basements which are $0.50 per square foot. All permit fees which are paid on a square foot basis include the following without any additional charges: 
(1)  Building permit; 
(2)  Plumbing permit; 
(3)  Electrical permit; 
(4)  Sewer and water permit; 
(5)  Fence permit; 
(6)  Driveway permit; 
(7)  Deck permit; 
(8)  Sidewalk permit; 
(9)  Detached garage permit; and 
(10)  All inspection fees. 
2.  Plumbing and sewer. Plumbing contractors are required to obtain the maximum surety bond required by state law and to present sufficient evidence of such surety to the village prior to obtaining the necessary permits from the village. 
3.  Electrical. Permits are required for electrical service upgrades not connected to construction. 
4.  Elevators or related devices. 
a.  Permits are required for the following and in the following amounts: 
Type of Work Amount of Fee New or altered elevators or related devices $100.00 Inspection fees: Semi-annual inspections $50.00 All reinspections $50.00

Activity Amount of Fee Installation or removal of fuel tanks or other tank containing hazardous liquids (EPA approval must be secured before the village will issue a permit) $1.00/per gallon  
6.  Signs. Permits are required for the following and in the following amounts. 
Alterations of billboards, sign boards, ground signs and painted wall signs $25.00 per face Erection and construction of billboards, sign boards, ground signs and painted wall signs $50.00 per face  
Any signs five square feet in area or less will not be required a separate permit or fee when those signs are installed with and relate to other sign(s) which require permit and for which the permit is granted and the fee paid. 
Temporary business signs or event banners, or balloons: 
0 to 30 days $50.00 31 to 60 days $100.00  
Temporary business signs, banners or balloons are allowed for a maximum of 60 days. No permit will be issued for a business sign, banner or balloon which has been displayed anywhere in the village within the 30 days prior to the application for a permit. 
7.  Roll-off boxes. 
a.  Permits are required for the following and in the following amounts: 
Activity Amount of Fee On parkway or street roll-off boxes (Maximum time allowed on parkway or street is 72 hours) $25.00  
8.  Demolition permit and fee. 
a.  Permits are required for demolition. Fees for demolition permits will be: $1.50 per square foot of residential building footprint; $1.00 per square foot of garage footprint; and $2.00 per square foot for each floor footprint both above and below grade of any business, commercial or manufacturing demolition project. 
b.  Cook County demolition permit required. A demolition permit from the County of Cook is required before a demolition permit from the village building department will be issued. 
9.  Permit renewal fees. In the event that a building permit extension or renewal is required, the fee for each subsequent annual period shall be the greater of the original fee or $100.00. 
C.  Repair or installation of water, sanitary or storm sewer service for: Commercial properties with a total job value estimate of no greater than $25,000; residential properties. Cash deposit and certificate of liability insurance required for excavation of a parkway, alley, or street. The fees, charges, surety and insurance required for repair or installation of: Residential water, sanitary or storm sewer service; or repair or installation of commercial water, sanitary or storm sewer service where the village engineer's estimate of total job value is no greater than $25,000.00, are as follows: 
1.  Excavation deposit. A cash deposit of $2,000.00 is required for the excavation of any parkway, alley, or street. 
2.  Refund of excavation deposit. 
a.  Upon the written request of the person or entity posting the cash bond and upon completion of the excavation, subject to deducting any costs incurred by the village, the building commissioner or his designee may authorize a refund of up to 90 percent of the cash deposit. 
b.  Upon the written request of the person or entity posting the cash deposit the village will refund the ten percent remainder of the cash deposit to the person or entity posting such deposit one year after the work is completed, subject to the deduction therefrom of any costs incurred by the village. 
3.  Certificate of liability insurance. A certificate of liability insurance, providing coverage of a minimum of $1,000,000.00 and naming the Village of Norridge as additional insured, shall be provided for an excavation on public property. 
D.  Surety bond required. 
1.  A surety bond in the amount of $10,000.00 listing the Village of Norridge as principal of the bond is required for the following: 
a.  Excavation. 
b.  Wrecking or demolition. 
(See section 38-82 for permit and surety requirements for excavation of a public parkway, alley, or street by nonresidential entities or utilities where the village engineer has estimated job cost to be in excess of $25,000.00. See section 38-82 for all public tree permit fees.) 
2.  Additional inspections beyond those required by permit shall be at a cost of $25.00 per inspection. Additional inspections required by building commissioner shall be at a cost of $25.00 per inspection. 
3.  Failure to acquire the proper permits prior to commencement of work shall double the permit fee, stop the job, and will result in citations being issued. 
E.  Transfer inspection fees. A fee shall be paid prior to the required inspection and the issuance of the transfer certificate. 
Application for transfer certificate\$100.00 
Fee for each additional inspection\25.00

Sec. 38-82. - Construction in the public right-of-way (nonresidential entities and utilities). 
    The fees or charges required by or referenced in chapter 82 for nonresidential entities not subject to the fees and insurance requirements of chapter 38, section 38-18 C and D, and utilities constructing, installing, or repairing facilities in the public right-of-way, are as follows: 
82-104. Construction Permit Fee ..... 5% of job cost or a minimum of $250.00, whichever is greater. 82-108. Insurance-Required amounts. Required coverages and limits-Unless otherwise provided by franchise, license, or similar agreement any person, utility or entity excavating, occupying or constructing any facility in the public right-of-way shall secure and maintain the following liability insurance policies insuring the person, utility or entity as named insured and naming the village, and its elected and appointed officers, officials, agents, and employees as additional insureds on the policies listed in subsections (a) and (b) below:  
(a)  Commercial general liability insurance, including premises-operations, explosion, collapse, and underground hazard (commonly referred to as "X," "C," and "U" coverages) and products-completed operations coverage with limits not less than: 
1.  Five million dollars for bodily injury or death to each person; 
2.  Five million dollars for property damage resulting from any one accident; and 
3.  Five million dollars for all other types of liability; 
(b)  Automobile liability for owned, non-owned and hired vehicles with a combined single limit of $1,000,000.00 for personal injury and property damage for each accident; 
(c)  Worker's compensation with statutory limits; and 
(d)  Employer's liability insurance with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 per employee and per accident. 
82-110. Security Fund.  
(a)  Form: A permittee shall provide the security fund to the village in the form, at the permittee's election, of cash, or an unconditional, irrevocable letter of credit in a form acceptable to the village and meeting the minimum requirements of section 82-110 of the Village Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Amount: Not less than 110 percent of the village engineer's estimated cost of completion, restoration to at least as good a condition as that existing prior to the construction under the permit, including reasonable, directly related costs that the village estimates are likely to be incurred if the permittee fails to perform such restoration. 
82-117C. Trees in the public right-of-way.  
(a)  Tree removal application fee ..... $75.00 
(b)  Tree plan review, if required ..... 50.00 
(c)  Tree removal permit, per tree ..... 125.00 
(d)  Tree removal permit for dead, hazardous and nuisance trees ..... 0.00 
(e)  Mitigation for public trees: 
1.  Replacement requirements- Public trees shall be replaced by trees in such number and of appropriate species such that the sum of the caliper of the new trees that are to be planted shall be equal to or greater than the sum of the DBH of the protected trees that have been damaged or removed, all as determined by the village arborist. 
2.  Mitigation- Replacement rate for public trees considers the size, condition rating and species rating of the trees requiring mitigation and is at the rate of .75 inch diameter of new tree for each one inch of diameter of trees removed. 
(f)  Cash tree replacement fee, per caliper inch ..... $125.00 
(Ord. No. 1600-07, § 4, 10-24-2007)

Chapters 39-41 - RESERVED 
Chapter 42 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; civil emergencies, ch. 26; open fires causing air pollution, § 34-65; burning of combustible materials prohibited, § 78-33; required improvements of fire hydrant for street and sidewalks, § 86-144. 
State Law reference- Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6; statutory powers relative to fire protection, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1 et seq.; fire safety, 425 ILCS 5/0.01 et seq. 

Sec. 42-1. - Conflagrations. 
    Except as authorized in this Code, no person shall burn or set fire to any leaves or other combustible material. 
(Code 1972, ch. 18, art. 2, § 5) 
Sec. 42-2. - Bonfires. 
    No person shall make or kindle any bonfire, except as specifically permitted by the fire chief. 
(Code 1972, ch. 18, art. 2, § 51) 
Sec. 42-3. - Obstructing view of fire hydrants. 
    No person shall plant, place or maintain any tree, bush, shrubbery, pole, sign or other object that covers or hides from view any fire hydrant in the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 18, art. 2, § 60) 
Secs. 42-4-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIREWORKS 

Sec. 42-31. - Definitions-Fireworks. 
A.  Except as provided in paragraph B. herein, "fireworks" shall mean and include any explosive composition, or any substance or combination of substances, or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect of a temporary exhibitional nature by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall include the following: 
1.  Those fireworks that must comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations of the U.S. Consumer Products Safety Commission, as set forth in 16 C.F.R. Parts 1500 and 1507, and classified as fireworks UN0336 or UN0337 by the United States Department of Transportation under 49 C.F.R. 172.101. 
2.  Blank cartridges. 
3.  Toy cannons in which explosives are used. 
4.  The type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same. 
5.  Firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, Roman candles, bombs or other devices of similar construction. 
6.  Any fireworks containing any explosive compound. 
7.  Any tablets or other devices containing any explosive substance, or containing combustible substances producing visual effects. 
B.  The term "fireworks" shall not include the following: 
1.  Snake or glow worm pellets. 
2.  Smoke devices. 
3.  Trick noisemakers known as "party poppers," "booby traps," "snappers," "trick matches," "cigarette loads," and "auto burglar alarms". 
4.  Sparklers. The term "sparklers" means a wire or stick coated with pyrotechnic composition which may not exceed 100 grams per item that produces a shower of sparks upon ignition. The term "sparklers" shall not include other sparkling devices including but not limited to items commonly known as "fountains," "spinners," "wheels," or similar devices, the sale and use of which is expressly prohibited. 
5.  Toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper or plastic caps containing 0.25 grains or less of explosive compound are used, provided they are so constructed that the hand cannot come in contact with the cap when in place for the explosion. 
6.  Toy pistol paper or plastic caps which contain less than 0.20 grains of explosive mixture. 
(Ord. No. 1618-08, § 2, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 42-32. - Prohibited activities. 
    No person shall manufacture, possess, store, offer for sale, expose for sale, sell at retail, use, display, ignite, or explode any fireworks. 
(Ord. No. 1618-08, § 2, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 42-33. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit the use of fireworks by railroads, public utilities, public and private carriers, or other transportation agencies, for signal purposes or illumination, or for signal purposes in athletics or sports, or for use by governmental organizations. 
(Ord. No. 1618-08, § 2, 6-11-2008) 
Sec. 42-34. - Penalty for violation of this article. 
A.  [Fine.] Any person who violates, disobeys or omits, neglects or refuses to comply with or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than the following: 
1.  Possession of fireworks. Not less than $50.00 nor more than $750.00. 
2.  Sale of fireworks. Not less than $250.00 nor more than $750.00. 
3.  Discharge of fireworks. Not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00. 
Each day that a violation is permitted to exist after notification thereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
B.  Confiscation of fireworks. In addition to all other penalties set forth in this Code, any fireworks adjudged by any court, or hearing officer in an administrative proceeding, to have been sold, used or transported by any person in violation of the provisions of this article shall be adjudged to be forfeited to, and may be confiscated by, the village. 
C.  Destruction of fireworks confiscated. Whenever any fireworks are surrendered or confiscated pursuant to the terms of this article, the police chief shall ascertain whether such fireworks are needed as evidence in any matter. If such fireworks are not required for evidence they shall be destroyed at the direction of the police chief. A record of the date and method of destruction and an inventory of the fireworks destroyed shall be maintained. 
(Ord. No. 1618-08, § 2, 6-11-2008)

Chapter 46 - FLOODS[1] 
Footnotes:
