ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-31. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a police department. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 1, § 1) 
Sec. 58-32. - Composition. 
    The police department shall consist of the chief of police, deputy chief of police, and such number of subordinate officers as are authorized by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 1, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1438-03, § 2(C), 2-26-2003; Ord. No. 1570-07, § 2, 5-9-2007) 
Sec. 58-33. - Appointments. 
A.  Chief of police, deputy chief of police, and commanders. The president, by and with the advice and consent of the village board, may appoint officers to be styled respectively chief of police, deputy chief of police, and commanders, who shall hold office at the pleasure of the president and board of trustees, except that such appointments shall expire with the municipal year, or until a successor is appointed and qualified. Provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prevent the village from entering into a contract with the appointed officers. 
B.  Appointment to supervisory ranks. Appointment to supervisory ranks shall be made from a promotional list provided by the board of police and fire commissioners. Such lists shall be effective for a period of three years from the date of creation. 
C.  Original appointments. Original appointments shall be made from an eligibility list provided by the board of police and fire commissioners. Such lists shall be effective for a period of three years from the date of creation. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 1, § 3; Ord. No. 1342-01, § 1, 5-23-2001; Ord. No. 1438-03, § 2(D), 2-26-2003; Ord. No. 1495-04, § 2, 10-13-2004; Ord. No. 1570-07, § 2, 5-9-2007) 
Sec. 58-34. - Duties of chief of police; deputy chief of police. 
A.  Chief. The chief of police shall be keeper of the village jail, and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein. He shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or by the village board. The chief shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of all its functions. 
B.  Deputy chief. The deputy chief of police shall have those duties assigned from time to time by the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 1, § 4; Ord. No. 1570-07, § 2, 5-9-2007) 
Sec. 58-35. - Regulations governing police officers. 
    The police officers of the village shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall be prescribed from time to time by the chief of police; provided, however, that no rule or regulation made or issued by the chief of police shall conflict with any rule or regulation which may be made by the president and board of trustees for the conduct and control of the police department. All rules and regulations made by the president and board of trustees shall be transmitted to the chief of police who shall, in turn, make such provisions as are necessary for their enforcement. 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 7, § 8) 
Sec. 58-36. - Authority of chief; duties of officers. 
    All members of the police department shall be directly under the chief of police, and shall aid and assist the chief of police in his functions as he may direct. It shall be the duty of each member of the police department to enforce all ordinances relative to the preserving of the peace, health and good order and quiet of the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 7, § 9; ch. 3, art. 1, § 1) 
Secs. 58-37-58-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PENSION FUND 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 58-61. - Established. 
    There is established a police pension fund under and in accordance with the provisions of article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 8, § 1) 
Sec. 58-62. - Money set apart. 
    There is set apart to constitute such fund the moneys so specified in article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 8, § 2) 
Sec. 58-63. - Annual report by treasurer. 
    On the second Tuesday in May annually, the treasurer and all other officials of the village who had the custody of any pension funds provided in this division, shall make a sworn statement to the board of trustees of the police pension fund, and to the president and board of trustees, of all moneys received and paid out by them on account of the pension fund during the year, and of the amount of funds then on hand and owing to the pension fund. All surplus then remaining with any official other than the treasurer shall be paid to the village treasurer. Upon demand of the board, any official shall furnish a statement relative to the official method of collection or handling of the pension funds. All books and records of that official shall be produced at any time by him for examination and inspection by the board. 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 8, § 6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-141. 
Secs. 58-64-58-80. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Board of Trustees[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-421 et seq. 

Sec. 58-81. - Membership. 
A.  A board of five members shall constitute a board of trustees to administer the pension fund and to designate the beneficiaries. The board shall be known as the board of trustees of the police pension fund. 
B.  Two members of the board shall be appointed by the president. 
C.  The third and fourth members of the boards shall be elected from the active participants of the pension fund by the active participants. The fifth member shall be elected by and from the beneficiaries. The members appointed by the mayor shall serve for one year or until their successors are appointed and qualified. Such terms begin on the second Tuesday in May. The election for board members shall be held biennially on the third Monday in April, at such place in the city and under the Australian ballot system and such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members of the board. The active pension fund participants shall be entitled to vote only for the active participant members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal age may vote only for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at such election. The term of elected members shall be two years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after the election. Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any elected board member, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special election, to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election. 
D.  Members of the board shall neither receive nor have any right to receive any salary from the pension fund for services performed as trustees in that office. 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 8, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. 1448-03, § 3, 4-23-2003) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-128. 
Sec. 58-82. - Meetings; vacancies. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall hold annually regular quarterly meetings in July, October, January and April, and special meetings as called by the president. At the regular July meeting, the board shall select from its members a president, vice-president, secretary and assistant secretary to serve for one year and until their respective successors are elected and qualified. The vice-president shall perform the duties of president during any vacancy in that office, or during the president's absence from the city or if he is by reason of illness or other causes unable to perform the duties of the office. The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary whenever necessary to discharge the functions of such office. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-130. 
Sec. 58-83. - Space for offices and meetings. 
    Suitable rooms for offices and meetings of such board shall be assigned by the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1972, ch. 2, art. 8, § 5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-129. 
Sec. 58-84. - Powers and duties. 
    The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall have the powers and duties stated as follows, in addition to the other powers and duties provided under article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.): 
1.  To control and manage the pension fund. In accordance with the applicable provisions of law, to control and manage, exclusively, the following: 
a.  The pension fund; 
b.  Investment expenditures and income, including interest dividends, capital gains and other distributions on the investments; and 
c.  All money donated, paid, assessed or provided by law for the pensioning of disabled and retired police officers, their surviving spouses, minor children and dependent parents. 
All money received or collected shall be credited by the village treasurer to the account of the pension fund and held by the treasurer subject to the order and control of the board. The village treasurer shall maintain a record of all money received, transferred and held for the account of the board. 
2.  To order payments and issue certificates. To order the payment of pensions and other benefits and to issue certificates signed by its president and secretary to the beneficiaries stating the amount and purpose of the payment. 
3.  To submit annual list of fund payments. To submit annually to the city council or board of trustees at the close of the fiscal year, a list of persons entitled to payments from the fund, stating the amount of payments, and their purpose, as ordered by the board. It shall also include items of income accrued to the fund during the fiscal year. The list shall be signed by the secretary and president of the board, and attested under oath. A resolution or order for the payment of money shall not be valid unless approved by a majority of the board members, and signed by the president and secretary of the board. 
4.  To invest funds. To invest funds in accordance with 40 ILCS 5/1-113.1, 5/1-113.10. 
5.  To subpoena witnesses. To compel witnesses to attend and testify before it upon all matters connected with the administration of the pension fund, in the manner provided by law for the taking of testimony in the circuit courts of this state. The president, or any board member, may administer oaths to witnesses. 
6.  To appoint clerk. To appoint a clerk and define his duties. No person drawing a pension under this division shall be employed by the board. 
7.  To pay expenses. To provide for the payment from the fund of all necessary expenses, including clerk hire, printing and witness fees. 
8.  To keep records. To keep a public record of all its proceedings. 
9.  To make rules. To make necessary rules and regulations in conformity with the provisions of law, and to publish and transmit copies from time to time to all pensioners and contributors. 
10.  To accept donations. To accept by gift, grant, transfer or bequest, any money, real estate or personal property. Such money and the proceeds from the sale of or the income from such real estate or personal property shall be paid into the pension fund. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-131-5/3-140.1. 
Sec. 58-85. - Report. 
A.  The board of trustees of the police pension fund shall report annually to the village board of trustees on the condition of the pension fund at the end of its most recently completed fiscal year. The report shall be made prior to the village board meeting held for the levying of taxes for the year for which the report is made. The board shall certify: 
1.  The assets of the fund in its custody at the end of the fiscal year; 
2.  The estimated receipts during the next succeeding fiscal year from deductions from the salaries of police officers, and from all other sources; 
3.  The estimated amount required during the next succeeding fiscal year to: 
a.  Pay all pensions and other obligations provided in this division; and 
b.  Meet the annual requirements of the fund as provided in 40 ILCS 5/3-125 and 5/3-127; and 
4.  The total net income received from investment of assets, compared to such income received during the preceding fiscal year. 
B.  Before the board makes its report, the village shall have the assets of the fund and their current market value verified by an independent certified public accountant of its choice. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 40 ILCS 5/3-143. 
Secs. 58-86-58-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AUXILIARY POLICE 

Sec. 58-111. - Duties. 
    Auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular police department of the village. Auxiliary police officers shall not supplement members of the regular police department in the performance of their assigned and normal duties, except as otherwise provided in this Code. Auxiliary police officers shall only be assigned to perform the following duties in the village: 
1.  Aid or direct traffic within the village; 
2.  Aid in control of natural or manmade disasters; and 
3.  Aid in case of civil disorder as directed by the chief of police. 
When it is impractical for members of the regular police department to perform those normal and regular police duties, however, the chief of police of the regular police department may assign auxiliary police officers to perform those normal and regular police duties, provided however that auxiliary police officer shall not have any of the duties of "conservator of the peace" as defined in 65 ILCS 5/3.1-15-25. Identification symbols worn by auxiliary police officers shall be different and distinct from those used by members of the regular police department. Auxiliary police officers shall at all times during the performance of their duties be subject to the direction and control of the village chief of police. Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms, except with the permission of the chief of police and while in uniform and in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 2, § 2; Ord. No. 1569-07, § 2, 4-25-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20(a). 
Sec. 58-112. - Training; fingerprinting. 
    Auxiliary police officers, before entering upon any of their duties, shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures appropriate for the exercise of the powers conferred upon them under this Code. The training and course of study shall be determined and provided by the corporate authorities of the village and shall be in accordance with the administrative procedures of the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board. Before the appointment of an auxiliary police officer, the person's fingerprints shall be taken, and no person shall be appointed as an auxiliary police officer if that person has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 2, § 2; Ord. No. 1569-07, § 2, 4-25-2007; Ord. No. 1572-07, § 2, 5-23-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20(b). 
Sec. 58-113. - State compensation act applicable in case of death. 
    The Line of Duty Compensation Act (820 ILCS 315/1 et seq.) shall be applicable to auxiliary police officers upon their death in the line of duty described in this article. 
(Code 1972, ch. 3, art. 2, § 2; Ord. No. 1569-07, § 2, 4-25-2007) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-20(c). 
Secs. 58-114-58-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ALARMS RESPONDED TO BY THE POLICE DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, adopted Aug. 28, 2002, enacted a new Art. IV, §§ 58-120-58-135. The newly enacted §§ 5-120-58-135 have been renumbered as set out herein at the discretion of the editor to preserve the style of the Code. 

Sec. 58-131. - Purpose. 
A.  The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm companies to maintain the operational reliability and proper use of alarm systems thereby reducing or eliminating false alarm dispatch requests. 
B.  This article governs residential and non-residential systems intended to summon police response, permit requirements, establishes fees, provides for fines and penalties for violations, establishes a system of administration, and sets conditions for suspension or loss of permits. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-132. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm administrator means the village chief of police or a person or persons designated by the village chief of police to administer and review alarm applications, permits, and to control alarm dispatch requests. 
    Alarm company means the business, by an individual, partnership, corporation or other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, installing or monitoring an alarm system at an alarm site or alarmed premises. 
    Alarm dispatch request means a notification to the police by a monitoring alarm company that an alarm, either manual or automatic, has been activated at a particular alarm site or alarmed premises. 
    Alarm registration (or permit) means the notification by an alarm company or an alarm user to the alarm administrator that an alarm system has been installed and is in use. 
    Alarm site or alarmed premises means a single premises or location served by an alarm system or systems. Each tenancy, if served by a separate alarm system in a multi-tenant building or complex, shall be considered a separate alarm site or alarmed premises. 
    Alarm system means a device or series of automatic or manual devices, intended to discourage crime by transmitting a remote signal to a monitoring center or by emitting a local audible or visual signal indicating an alarm condition. Alarm system does not include: 
1.  An alarm installed on a vehicle unless the vehicle is permanently located at a site; or 
2.  An alarm designed to alert only the inhabitants of a premises that does not have a sounding device which can be heard on the exterior of the alarm site and does not transmit a remote signal to a monitoring center. 
    Alarm user means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity who (which) uses an alarm system at its alarm site or alarmed premises. 
    Arming station means a device that allows control of an alarm system by the entering of a coded sequence of numbers or letters or other information, either manually or with the use of a FOB or a biometrics device such as a fingerprint reader. 
    Cancellation or responding agency alarm dispatch cancellation is the process by which a monitoring alarm company verifies with the alarm user or responsible party that an alarm signal has been identified as being a false alarm and that there is not an existing situation at the alarm site requiring law enforcement agency response. 
    Conversion means the transaction or process by which one alarm company assumes the servicing or monitoring of an alarm system previously monitored by another alarm company. 
    Current counting or billing period means a 12-month period beginning May 1 of each year. 
    Duress alarm means a silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal that an alarm user is in a personal jeopardy situation requiring police response. 
    False alarm dispatch means an alarm dispatch request to the police department, when the responding officer finds no evidence of a criminal offense or attempted criminal offense after having completed a timely investigation of the alarm site. An alarm dispatch request which is canceled by the monitoring alarm company or the alarm user prior to the time the responding officer reaches the alarm site shall not be considered a false alarm dispatch. 
    False alarm response fee means the fee charged by the village for responding to a false alarm dispatch. 
    Holdup alarm means a silent alarm signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a robbery in progress. 
    Monitoring means the process by which a monitoring alarm company receives signals from alarm systems and relays an alarm dispatch request to the village for the purpose of summoning police response to the alarm site. 
    Monitoring alarm company means an entity which receives alarm signals from alarm users, and takes appropriate action which might include verification with alarm users and/or notification to law enforcement that emergency response is requested. The alarm users may be direct customers of the alarm monitoring company or alternately may be customers of a servicing alarm company which has retained the services of the monitoring alarm company to provide monitoring services. 
    Monitoring center means a facility operated by a monitoring alarm company which receives alarm signals from alarm users, and which takes appropriate action which might include verification with alarm users and for notification to law enforcement that emergency response is requested. 
    One plus duress alarm means the manual activation of a silent alarm signal by entering at a keypad a code that adds one to the last digit of the normal arm/disarm code (normal code = 1234 one plus duress code = 1235). 
    Panic means an audible alarm system signal generated by the manual activation of a device intended to signal a life-threatening or emergency situation requiring law enforcement response. 
    Servicing alarm company means the entity responsible to provide training, repair and service, as well as communication with the alarm user relative to false alarm problems. 
    Takeover means the transaction or process by which an alarm user takes over control of an existing alarm system which was previously controlled by another alarm user. 
    Verify means an attempt, by the monitoring alarm company to contact the alarm site by telephonic or other electronic means, whether or not actual contact with a person is made, before requesting a police dispatch, in an attempt to avoid an unnecessary alarm dispatch request. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002; Ord. No. 1418-02, § 2, 9-25-2002) 
Sec. 58-133. - Permit required. 
A.  No alarm user shall operate, or cause to be operated, an alarm system at its alarm site without a valid alarm permit issued by the alarm administrator. A separate permit is required for each alarm site. 
B.  The annual fee for a permit or permit renewal for a residential alarm site is $25.00. The annual fee for a permit or permit renewal for a commercial alarm site is $50.00. No refund of a permit or permit renewal fee will be made. The initial annual permit fee must be submitted to the alarm administrator prior to the alarm installation or alarm takeover. 
C.  Upon receipt of a completed, signed application form and the permit fee, the alarm administrator shall issue an alarm permit to an applicant unless the applicant has: 
1.  Failed to pay a fine or fee assessed under this article; or 
2.  Had an alarm permit for the alarm site suspended or revoked, and the violation causing the suspension or revocation has not been corrected. 
D.  Each permit application must include the following information: 
1.  Name and address of the applicant; 
2.  Name and address of the property owner if different from the applicant; 
3.  Name and address of the alarmed premises (name of business or homeowner); 
4.  The name, address, and telephone numbers of the person who will be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this article; 
5.  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least three persons responsible for the alarm site or alarmed premises where the security alarm system is located; 
6.  If different from those persons listed in subsections 1., 2., and 3. of this section D., the names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least three persons who should be called and who will respond to the alarmed premises if requested in the event the security alarm is activated; 
7.  The classification of the alarm site as either residential or commercial; 
8.  For each alarm system located at the alarm site, the purpose of the alarm system, i.e., burglary, holdup, duress, or other; 
9.  The date of installation, conversion or takeover of the alarm system, whichever is applicable; 
10.  The name, address, phone number, fax number, e-mail, if any, and contact person of the servicing alarm company performing the alarm system installation, conversion or alarm system takeover and responsible for providing repair service to the alarm system; 
11.  The name, address, and phone number of the monitoring alarm company monitoring the alarm system if different from the installing alarm company; 
12.  A statement that a set of written operating instructions for the alarm system, including written guidelines on how to avoid alarms, have been left with the applicant; and 
13.  A statement that the alarm company has trained the applicant in proper use of the alarm system, including instructions on how to avoid false alarms. 
E.  Any false statement of a material matter made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining an alarm permit shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a permit. 
F.  An alarm permit cannot be transferred to another alarm user. An alarm user shall inform the alarm administrator of any change that alters any information listed on the permit application within five business days. 
G.  All fees owed by an applicant must be paid before a permit may be issued or renewed. 
H.  Information contained in permit applications shall be held in confidence by all employees or representatives of the village with access to such information. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-134. - Permit duration and renewal. 
    A permit shall expire on April 30 of each year, and must be renewed annually by submitting updated information, if applicable, and a permit renewal fee to the alarm administrator. The alarm administrator shall notify each alarm user of the need to renew at least 30 days prior to the expiration of their permit. It is the responsibility of the alarm user to submit an application prior to the permit expiration date. Failure to renew will be classified as use of a non-permitted alarm system and citations and appropriate penalties shall be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002; Ord. No. 1418-02, § 2, 9-25-2002) 
Sec. 58-135. - Proper alarm system operation and maintenance. 
A.  An alarm user shall: 
1.  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarm dispatches; 
2.  Make every reasonable effort to respond or cause a representative to respond to the alarm system's location within 30 minutes when notified by the monitoring alarm company or municipality to deactivate an alarm system, to provide access to the premises, or to provide security for the premises; and 
3.  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report. 
B.  An alarm user shall adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an audible alarm signal on the exterior of an alarm site will sound for no longer than ten minutes after being activated (or 15 minutes for systems operating under Underwriters Laboratories, Inc. Standard 827). 
C.  An alarm user shall have a property licensed alarm company inspect the alarm system at a minimum once per year or after two false alarms in a counting period. The alarm administrator may waive an inspection requirement if it determines that a false alarm(s) could not have been related to a defect or malfunction in the alarm system. After four false alarms within one counting period the alarm user must have a properly licensed alarm company modify the alarm system to be more false alarm resistant or provide additional user training as appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-136. - Monitoring procedures. 
A.  An alarm monitoring company performing monitoring services shall: 
1.  Report alarm signals to the law enforcement jurisdiction by using telephone numbers designated by the alarm administrator or, alternately, by transmission of the alarm dispatch data by electronic means acceptable to the law enforcement jurisdiction; 
2.  Attempt to verify every alarm signal, except a hold-up alarm activation before requesting a police response to an alarm signal; 
3.  Communicate verified cancellations of alarm dispatch requests to the village in a manner and form determined by the alarm administrator; 
4.  Ensure that all alarm users of alarm systems equipped with duress alarm are given adequate training as to the proper use of the duress alarm by the servicing alarm company; and 
5.  Endeavor to contact the alarm user when an alarm dispatch request is made and require response to the premises within 30 minutes by the alarm user representative or their designated agent. 
B.  The alarm administrator shall designate a manner, form and telephone numbers for the communication of alarm dispatch requests and verified alarm dispatch cancellations, or alternately, designate the form and content of the electronic alarm dispatch data and cancellations. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-137. - Alarm system operating instructions. 
    An alarm user shall maintain, at each alarm site, a set of written operating instructions for each alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-138. - Alarm dispatch request records. 
A.  The officer responding to an alarm dispatch request shall record such information as necessary to permit the alarm administrator to maintain records, including, but not limited, to the following information: 
1.  Identification of the alarm site; 
2.  Arrival time at the alarm site and dispatch received time; 
3.  Date; 
4.  Weather conditions and other relevant information such as power or telephone line failures; 
5.  Area and/or sub-area of premise involved; and 
6.  Name of alarm user's representative on premises or the identity of the person responding on behalf of the alarm user. 
B.  The responding police officer shall indicate his or her opinion on the dispatch report as to whether the dispatch was caused by a criminal offense, an attempted criminal offense, or was a false alarm dispatch. 
C.  Alarm companies which perform monitoring services must maintain, for a period of at least one-year following request for police dispatch to an alarm site, records relating to the dispatch. Records must include the name, address and phone number of the alarm user, the alarm system zone(s) or point(s) activated, the time of request for police dispatch and evidence that an attempt to verify was made to the alarm site prior to the request for police dispatch. The alarm administrator may request copies of such records for individually named alarm users. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-139. - System performance reviews. 
    If there is reason to believe that an alarm system is not being used or maintained in a manner that ensures proper operation and suppresses false alarms, the alarm administrator may require a conference with an alarm user and the alarm company responsible for the repair of the alarm system to review the circumstances of each false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-140. - False alarm response fees; fines. 
A.  A false alarm response fee is hereby imposed on all security alarm users to reimburse the village for the increased costs incurred to provide response services to false security alarms from any security alarm system. An alarm user shall be subject to false alarm response fees, warnings and suspension or revocation of permit depending on the number of false alarm dispatches emitted from an alarm system within a 12-month period beginning May 1 of each year (the current counting and billing period) based upon the following schedule: 
Number of False Alarm Dispatches Action Taken False Alarm Response Fees 1 Warning Notice #1 $0.00 2 Warning Notice #2 $0.00 3 $50.00 4 $50.00 5 $100.00 6 $100.00 7 $200.00 8 & Up 30-day notice of impending alarm permit suspension $200.00  
False alarm response fees will be assessed each time there is a false security alarm in the amounts set forth above. 
B.  In addition, any person operating a non-permitted alarm system, whether revoked, suspended or never acquired, will be subject to a citation and assessment of a $200.00 fine for each false alarm dispatch, in addition to any other fines or fees applicable based on the number of false alarms in the current counting and billing period. The alarm administrator may waive this additional fine for a non-permitted system if the alarm user applies for a permit within ten days after such violation. 
C.  If cancellation occurs prior to law enforcement arriving at the scene, it is not a false alarm for the purpose of fees or false alarm count and no fees will be assessed. 
D.  Alarm dispatch requests, caused by an actual criminal offense or with evidence of a criminal attempt, or caused by weather conditions, or power failures lasting more than 1 hour, shall not be counted as a false alarm dispatch. 
E.  The alarm administrator may reinstate a suspended permit upon receipt of acceptable evidence that the cause has been addressed and appropriate corrective action has been taken as outlined in this article. Alarm events recorded on a year-to-date basis shall remain of record, and any subsequent false alarm chargeable event shall be assessed at the appropriate rate for the accumulated alarm events which have occurred in the current counting and billing period. 
F.  In addition to the provisions of this section, the village may take any other lawful action to collect arrearages for invoices for reimbursement of false alarm response fees. Any delinquent account shall be subject to a service charge equal to three percent per month of the amount then due. The three percent service charge shall be added to the amount then due each month that any part of the charge is delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002; Ord. No. 1418-02, § 2, 9-25-2002) 
Sec. 58-141. - Revocation, suspension or loss of alarm permit. 
A.  The alarm administrator may suspend the alarm permit and alarm response if it is determined that: 
1.  The alarm user has eight or more false alarms in the calendar year and has received a 30-day notice and such 30-day period has expired without an adequate reinstatement remedy or appeal; or 
2.  There is a false statement of a material fact in the application for a registration; or 
3.  The alarm user has failed to make timely payment of a fine or fee assessed under this article; or 
4.  The alarm user has failed to submit a written certification from an alarm company stating that the alarm system has been inspected and repaired (if necessary) by the alarm company when such inspection has been requested by the alarm administrator. 
B.  A person commits an offense if he operates an alarm system during the period in which his alarm permit is suspended or revoked. The fee assessed for such an offense shall be the same as that defined for a "no permit" false alarm dispatch. 
C.  Unless there is separate indication that there is a crime in progress, the law enforcement authority may refuse police response to an alarm dispatch request at an alarm site for which no permit exists or the alarm permit is revoked or suspended. 
D.  If a suspended or revoked alarm permit is reinstated, the alarm administrator may revoke the alarm permit if it is determined that two subsequent false alarm dispatches occur during the remainder of the current counting or billing period. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-142. - Appeal from denial, suspension or revocation of a permit. 
A.  If the alarm administrator denies the issuance or renewal of a permit, or sends a 30-day notice of the intention to suspend or revoke a permit, he or she shall send written notice of this action, by mail, to the applicant or alarm user. 
B.  The alarm user may submit new information to the alarm administrator relating to the repair, remedy of the problem or replacement of the system. The administrator shall review this new information and reject the information as inadequate to assure that the problem is solved, or, alternately, consider the problem or the causes of false alarms to be adequately addressed and subsequently issue, renew or reinstate the permit, or, if relevant, cancel the suspension notice. 
C.  The applicant or alarm user may appeal the decision of the alarm administrator to the alarm administrator by filing a written request for a review setting forth the reasons for the appeal within 20 days after receipt of the notice of denial or suspension from the alarm administrator. An alarm company may submit the request for review on behalf of an alarm user. 
D.  Filing of a request for appeal shall stay the action by the alarm administrator suspending, denying or revoking a permit until the alarm administrator has completed his/her review. If a request for appeal is not made within the 20-day period set forth in subsection C. above, the action of the alarm administrator is final. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-143. - Reinstatement of permit. 
    An alarm user whose alarm permit has been suspended may reinstate its permit if the alarm user: 
1.  Pays, or otherwise resolves, all fees, citations and fines and notifies the alarm administrator of such fact, and/or; 
2.  Submits a certification from the servicing alarm company, stating that the alarm system has been inspected and repaired or replaced (if necessary) by the alarm company, and/or; 
3.  Has satisfied the alarm administrator that a satisfactory resolution of the problem is completed. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-144. - Limitation on audible alarms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any security alarm user to cause or permit an audible alarm signal to continue to emit an audible sound, which can be heard outside of the alarmed premises, unabated in excess of 15 minutes. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-145. - Non-assumption of liability. 
A.  The village assumes no liability for any defects in the operation of any security alarm system or for the failure or neglect of any person associated with the installation, operation or maintenance of a security alarm system; for the transmissions of security alarm signals; for the relaying of such signals and messages; for the failure or neglect of any security alarm user; for the transmission or receipt of alarm signals; or for any failure or neglect to respond upon receipt of a security alarm signal from any source. 
B.  In the event the village finds it necessary to revoke any direct connect security alarm registration, or to otherwise provide for the disconnection of any security alarm system, the village shall have no liability for such action. 
C.  No special duty other than that owed to the general public shall be created by virtue of this article, by virtue of the issuance of a direct connect security alarm registration by the village, or as a result of the transmission to or receipt of security alarm signals by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Sec. 58-146. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any other fines, fees or charges established herein, any person convicted of a violation of section 58-144 of this article may be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1411-02, § 2, 8-28-2002) 
Chapters 59-61 - RESERVED 
Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes:
