(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 11, § 4) 
Sec. 94-42. - Functions of police. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the police department to patrol the public highways and to make arrests for violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  It shall be the duty of the police department to investigate traffic accidents. The police department shall maintain a suitable system of filing traffic accident reports. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 1, §§ 4, 12, 13) 
Sec. 94-43. - Signs to be erected. 
    It shall be the duty of the public works director to post adequate signs, where such signs may be necessary, for the effective enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 1, § 6, ch. 9, art. 4, § 12(b), ch. 9, art. 4, § 28, ch. 9, art. 4, § 30, ch. 9, art. 4, § 32(a), ch. 9, art. 6, § 3) 
State Law reference- When signs required, 625 ILCS 5/11-207, 5/11-208(b), 5/11-208.2. 
Sec. 94-44. - Intersection markers, buttons or signs regulating turning. 
    The public works director may cause markers, buttons or signs to be placed within or adjacent to intersections and thereby require and direct that a different course from that specified by law be traveled by turning at an intersection. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 4, § 23(d)) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate turning, 625 ILCS 5/11-207, 5/11-208(a)(9), 5/11-208.2, 5/11-801(3); obedience to turn indicators, 625 ILCS 5/11-801(3). 
Secs. 94-45-94-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGULATION OF TRAFFIC IN SHOPPING CENTERS AND APARTMENT COMPLEXES AND ON SCHOOL LANDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Agreements for enforcement in shopping centers, apartment complexes and schools, 625 ILCS 5/11-209. 

Sec. 94-71. - Agreements with owners and village president. 
    The president of the village is authorized to enter into and execute agreements with the owners of shopping centers, apartment complexes and school boards pursuant to the provisions of the 625 ILCS 5/11-209. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 10-A, § 1) 
Sec. 94-72. - Form of agreement. 
    Any agreement entered into by the president on behalf of the village shall be in substantially the following form: 
AGREEMENT 
REGULATING PARKING OF MOTOR VEHICLES AND CONTROL OF MOTOR VEHICLE TRAFFIC IN THE VILLAGE OF NORRIDGE, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS. 
    THIS AGREEMENT made and entered into by and between the Village of Norridge, a municipal corporation of the State of Illinois, and by its duly authorized owners, agents and representatives, hereinafter referred to as "owners," such ____________ being situated at _____ _____ in the Village of Norridge, and legally described as set forth below: 
[LEGAL DESCRIPTION] 
WITNESSETH: 
    WHEREAS, 625 ILCS 5/11-209, authorized and empowers a municipality to enter into agreements with owners of shopping centers and apartment complexes as defined therein for the regulation and control of motor vehicle traffic and parking on private property within the municipality; and 
    WHEREAS, the Village of Norridge is a home rule municipality in accordance with Article VII Section 6(a) of the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, and has enacted various ordinances providing for the protection of the health, safety and general welfare of the village including the regulation of parking and traffic related ordinances on public and private property; and 
    WHEREAS, the president and board of trustees of the Village of Norridge deem it necessary for the health, welfare and safety of persons and citizens to regulate and control motor vehicle traffic and parking in the ____________ in the Village of Norridge; and 
    WHEREAS, based on the authority of 625 ILCS 5/11-209 and its home rule authority the village and the owners of the ____________ are in agreement and desire the Village of Norridge and its police department to enforce certain regulations regarding motor vehicle traffic and parking in the aforesaid ____________ ; 
    NOW, THEREFORE, IT IS HEREBY AGREED and in consideration of the covenants and agreements hereinafter contained, to be kept and performed by the parties hereto, as follows: 
1.  The village hereby agrees to establish and enforce the following regulations regarding motor vehicle movement, parking and control within the parking lot of owners: 
a.  Permanent stop signs shall be posted at all exits into a public highway from the parking lot, and the driver of a motor vehicle emerging from the parking lot into a public highway shall first come to a complete full stop at such sign prior to proceeding into the public highway. 
b.  All motor vehicle movement shall be within the designated traffic lanes and, where marked by arrow or posted "one-way," no motor vehicle movement shall be in the opposite direction. 
c.  No motor vehicle shall be stopped or parked on the roadway or driveway which lies directly in front of the stores or buildings. 
d.  The stopping, standing or parking of any motor vehicle within the parking lot between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., shall be prohibited, except that any motor vehicle having affixed thereto on the windshield a decal or sticker, constituting a parking permit issued by the owners, shall not be subject to this regulation. 
e.  The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle within the shopping center (other than in the designated parking lot) by person or persons having no business establishments within the shopping center, or within the parking lot of an apartment complex, by person or persons not invited by the residents or owners of the apartment complex, shall be prohibited. 
f.  The stopping, standing or parking of motor vehicles by the operators thereof for the purpose of congregating or meeting shall be prohibited. 
g.  No motor vehicle shall be so operated as to cause or produce unnecessary loud, raucous, excessive or unusual noises, by the playing of vehicle radio, or by the racing of the motor, or by lack of muffler or use of a muffler cutout, by tire friction upon rapid turning or weaving, or by spinning of wheels from standing or slow moving position produced by sudden unnecessary acceleration, or by continuous unnecessary sound of a horn or other noise or signal device. 
h.  The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle within a designated posted fire lane, traffic lane or safety zone shall be prohibited, and no motor vehicle shall be left standing, stopped or parked within 20 feet in any direction from a fire hydrant, wall hydrant, water standpipe or fire exit door. 
i.  The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle, where so marked with parking stripes, shall be within and confined to such area. 
j.  The operating or parking of a motor vehicle that does not meet the requirements of: 
(1)  The village ordinances relating to vehicle licensing; or 
(2)  The provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code relating to vehicle registration; shall be prohibited, and the village shall be permitted to enforce all such ordinances and provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code on the above-described property. 
k.  The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle within 500 feet of any fire or police vehicle that has responded to a call or an alarm shall be prohibited. 
l.  The operating of an unlicensed go-kart, mini-bike or other miniature vehicle shall be prohibited. 
m.  The maximum speed limit for any motor vehicle shall not exceed 15 miles per hour within the parking lot. 
n.  Any motor vehicles parked or abandoned during a snow storm, flood, fire, or other public emergency, or found unattended in the parking area, where they constitute an obstruction to traffic or where stopping, standing or parking is prohibited, shall be removed and stored by a towing company designated by the police department of the Village of Norridge, and payment of reasonable charges for such removal and storage shall be paid by the owner or operator of such vehicle to the designated towing company. 
o.  No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the parking lot in such a manner as to constitute a hazard or to endanger the safety and convenience of the public or of the users of the parking area. 
p.  Immobilization of any eligible vehicle (as set forth in Section 94-121 et seq. of Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002 or as hereafter amended from time to time) by placement of a wheel restraint device so as to prevent its operation or, if the eligible vehicle is parked or left in violation of any provision of the traffic code for which such vehicle is subject to an immediate tow, or in any place where it constitutes an obstruction or a hazard or where it impedes village workers during such operations as snow removal, the village chief of police may cause the eligible vehicle to be towed to a village vehicle pound or relocated to a legal parking place and there restrained. 
2.  The owners do hereby agree to erect and post all necessary signs for the regulation of motor vehicle parking and traffic as is necessary to carry out the aforesaid village parking and traffic regulations, and does hereby agree to bear the costs and expense of same, and the maintenance thereof. 
3.  The Village of Norridge hereby agrees to regulate the parking of motor vehicle traffic in the parking lot of the owners in accordance with the aforesaid regulations. 
4.  It is hereby mutually agreed that this agreement shall be for a period of one year from the date hereof, and shall be self-renewing for periods of one year each thereafter, unless and until cancelled by not less than 30 days' written notice by either party to the other of its intention to cancel same. It is understood and agreed by the parties hereto, however, that the aforesaid regulations which affect fire lanes, fire hydrants, or which may be requested or required by any fire protection district or fire department, shall not be cancelled. 
    IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties hereto have set their hands and seals this ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ . 
Village of Norridge, 
A Municipal Corporation BY: ____________ BY: _____ ATTEST: ____________ ATTEST: _____  
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 10-A, § 2; Ord. No. 1810-14, § 2, 10-22-2014) 
Sec. 94-73. - Recording of agreements. 
    The village clerk shall cause to be recorded in the county recorder's office any agreement entered into by the president on behalf of the village. The traffic regulations shall be in full force and effect three days after the date of such recording. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 10-A, § 4) 
Sec. 94-74. - Applicable traffic regulations. 
    All traffic regulations provided for by this chapter and by the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.) shall be applicable to any motor vehicles using the property of any shopping center, apartment complex or school district which shall have entered into an agreement with the village as provided in this division. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 10-A, § 3) 
Sec. 94-75. - Violation of division provisions. 
    No person shall violate any applicable traffic regulation upon the property of any shopping center, apartment complex or school district which shall have entered into a duly recorded agreement with the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 10-A, § 5) 
Secs. 94-76-94-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ABANDONED AND INOPERABLE VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/4-201 et seq. 

Sec. 94-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indications a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle means all motor vehicles or other vehicles in a state of disrepair rendering the vehicle incapable of being driven in its condition; or any other motor vehicle or other vehicle that has not been moved or used for 72 consecutive hours or more and is apparently deserted. 
    Antique vehicle means any motor vehicle or other vehicle which is 25 years of age or older. 
    Highway means any street, ally or public way within the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 1; Ord. No. 1487-04, § 2, 7-28-2004) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 94-102. - Police to be notified. 
    When an abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle comes into the temporary possession or custody of a person in this state, not the owner of the vehicle, such person shall immediately notify the village police department when the vehicle is within the corporate limits of the village. Upon receipt of such notification, the police chief shall authorize a towing service to remove and take possession of the abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed motor vehicle or other vehicle. The towing service will safely keep the towed vehicle and its contents and maintain a record of the tow until the vehicle is claimed by the owner or any other person legally entitled to its possession, or until it is disposed of as provided by law. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/4-202. 
Sec. 94-103. - Antique vehicles exempted. 
    A motor vehicle or other vehicle classified as an antique vehicle is excluded from this division. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 10) 
Sec. 94-104. - Removal of vehicle. 
A.  When a motor vehicle is abandoned on a highway in this village ten hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be authorized by order of the police chief. 
B.  When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, burned or partially dismantled motor vehicle or other vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its position in relation to the highway or its physical appearance is causing the impeding of traffic, its immediate removal from the highway by a towing service may be authorized by order of the police chief. 
C.  When a vehicle removal from either public or private property is authorized by order of the police chief, the owner of the vehicle will be responsible for all towing costs. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 4) 
State Law reference- Vehicle removal, 625 ILCS 5/4-203. 
Sec. 94-105. - Recordkeeping. 
    When a motor vehicle or other vehicle is authorized to be towed away, the police department shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed, listing the color, year of manufacture, manufacturer's trade name, manufacturer's series name, body style, vehicle identification number and license plate year and number displayed on the vehicle. The record shall also include the date and hour of tow, location towed from, location towed to, reason for towing and the name of the officer authorizing the tow. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 5) 
Sec. 94-106. - Ownership information. 
A.  When the village police department does not know the identity of the registered owner or other legally entitled person, they will cause the motor vehicle registration records of the state to be searched by a directed communication to the secretary of state for the purpose of obtaining the required ownership information. 
B.  The police department will cause the stolen motor vehicle files of the state police to be searched by a directed communication to the state police for stolen or wanted information on the vehicle. When the state police files are searched with negative results, the information contained in the National Crime Information Center (NCIC) files will be searched by the state police. The information determined from these record searches will be used by the police department in sending a notification by certified mail to the owner or legally entitled person advising where the vehicle is held, requesting a disposition be made and setting forth public sale information. 
C.  When the registered owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle cannot be identified from the registration files of this state or from the registration files of a foreign state, if applicable, the police department shall notify the state police for the purpose of identifying the vehicle's owner or other person legally entitled to the possession of the vehicle. The information obtained by the state police will be immediately forwarded to the law enforcement agency having custody of the vehicle for notification of the owner. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, §§ 6, 7) 
State Law reference- Record searches, 625 ILCS 5/4-205, 5/4-206. 
Sec. 94-107. - Reclaiming vehicle. 
    Any time before a motor vehicle or other vehicle is sold at public sale or disposed of as provided in this division, the owner or other person legally entitled to its possession may reclaim the vehicle by presenting to the police department proof of ownership or proof of the right to possession of the vehicle. No vehicle shall be released to the owner or other person under this section until all towing and storage charges have been paid. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/4-207. 
Sec. 94-108. - Police not liable. 
    Any police officer, towing service owner, operator or employee shall not be held to answer or be liable for damages in any action brought by the registered owner, former registered owner or his legal representative, or any other person legally entitled to the possession of a motor vehicle or other vehicle when the vehicle was processed and sold or disposed of as provided by this division. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 8, § 13) 
Secs. 94-109-94-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VEHICLE IMMOBILIZATION 

Sec. 94-121. - Program authorized. 
    The village chief of police is authorized to direct and supervise a program of vehicle immobilization for the purpose of enforcing compliance with the village parking and other ordinances as provided in this division. The program of vehicle immobilization shall provide for immobilizing any eligible vehicle upon the public way, public property, or private property with the consent of the property owner, by placement of a wheel restraint device in such a manner as to prevent its operation or, if the eligible vehicle is parked or left in violation of any provision of the traffic code for which such vehicle is subject to an immediate tow, or in any place where it constitutes an obstruction or a hazard or where it impedes village workers during such operations as snow removal, the village chief of police may cause the eligible vehicle to be towed to a village vehicle pound or relocated to a legal parking place and there restrained. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(1), 1-23-2002; Ord. No. 1810-14, § 3, 10-22-2014) 
Sec. 94-122. - Immobilization list. 
    A vehicle shall also be eligible for immobilization as provided in this division any time after inclusion of its state registration number or vehicle information number ("VIN") on an immobilization list. A vehicle state registration number or VIN shall be included on an immobilization list only if: 
1.  The registered owner of the vehicle has accumulated five or more parking violation complaints in the village on which no payment has been made, on which no adjudication has occurred, or appearance filed within the time specified by the complaints. 
2.  At least 21 days prior to placing the vehicle state registration number or VIN of the vehicle on the immobilization eligibility list, notice of impending vehicle immobilization has been sent to the registered owner of the vehicle via first class mail, postage prepaid, at the address of the registered owner recorded with the Illinois Secretary of State or, in the case of a vehicle bearing a vehicle state registration number of a state other than Illinois, at the address of the registered owner recorded in that state's registry of motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(2), 1-23-2002; Ord. No. 1894-17, § 2, 5-10-2017) 
Sec. 94-123. - Notice of impending immobilization. 
    The notice required in section 94-122, subsection 2., shall state the name and address of the registered owner, the state registration number of the vehicle, the nature of the ordinances violated and the numbers and issue dates of the outstanding complaints. The notice shall also advise that a person may challenge the validity of the notice of impending vehicle immobilization by appearing in person and submitting evidence which would conclusively disprove liability, such as the following: 
1.  That the person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the dates the notices of parking violations were issued; 
2.  That the fines or penalties for the violations cited in the notice have been paid in full; or 
3.  That the registered owner has not accumulated five or more parking violation complaints in the village which are unpaid, not adjudicated or for which no appearance has been filed at the time that the notice was issued. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(3), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-124. - Challenge to validity of notice. 
    A person may challenge the validity of the notice of impending vehicle immobilization by requesting a hearing and appearing in person to submit evidence which would conclusively disprove liability within 21 days of the date of the notice. Documentary evidence which would conclusively disprove liability shall be based on the following grounds: 
1.  That the person was not the owner or lessee of the vehicle on the dates the notices of parking violations were issued; 
2.  That the fines or penalties for the violations cited in the notice have been paid in full; or 
3.  That the registered owner has not accumulated five or more parking violation complaints in the village which are unpaid, not adjudicated or for which no appearance has been filed at the time that the notice was issued. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(4), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-125. - Notice upon immobilization. 
    Upon immobilization of an eligible vehicle, a notice shall be affixed to the vehicle in a conspicuous place. Such notice shall warn that the vehicle is immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle may result in its damage. The notice shall also state that the unauthorized removal of or damage to the immobilizing restraint is a violation of sections 16-1 and/or 21-1 of the Illinois Criminal Code. The notice also shall provide information specifying how release of the immobilizing restraint may be had, and how the registered owner may obtain an immobilization hearing pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(5), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-126. - Towing and impoundment. 
    Except where the vehicle is otherwise subject to towing, if the immobilizing restraint has not been released pursuant to section 94-124 within 24 hours of its placement, the immobilization restraint shall be released and the vehicle towed and impounded. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(6), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-127. - Release of vehicle. 
    Prior to a hearing on the validity of the immobilization as provided in section 94-129, the owner of an immobilized vehicle or other authorized person shall be permitted to secure release of the vehicle by: 
1.  Paying the immobilization and towing and storage fees, if applicable, specified in section 94-130; and 
2.  Taking one of the following actions: 
a.  Paying all the fines and penalties, if any, on the outstanding complaints for which notice had been sent prior to the date of the immobilization; or 
b.  Filing Completing appearance forms and requesting a local adjudication date on all outstanding parking violation complaints for which notice had been sent prior to the date of the immobilization and depositing collateral in the amount of 50 percent of the total fines for these outstanding parking violation complaints, or $500.00, whichever is less. The collateral shall be in the form of United States currency, money order or certified check. No credit cards or personal checks shall be accepted; or 
c.  Filing a written demand for a hearing as provided for in section 94-129 of this Code and depositing a bond in the amount of 100 percent of the total amount as specified in the Notice of Pending Immobilization. The bond shall be in the form of United States currency, money order or certified check. No credit cards or personal checks shall be accepted. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(7), 1-23-2002; Ord. No. 1810-14, § 3, 10-22-2014) 
Sec. 94-128. - Notice of impoundment. 
    Within ten days after a vehicle has been impounded, notice of impoundment shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the registered owner of the vehicle at the address to which the notice specified in section 94-122, subsection 2., was mailed. The notice shall state that the owner has the right to a postimmobilization and posttowing hearing as provided in section 94-129, and that if the vehicle is not claimed within 30 days from the date of the notice, the vehicle may be sold or otherwise disposed of in accordance with 625 ILCS 5/4-208 and 625 ILCS 5/4-209. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(8), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-129. - Pre and post immobilization hearing. 
    The owner of an immobilized vehicle shall have the right to a hearing to determine whether the immobilization or any subsequent towing was erroneous or whether the vehicle was properly included on an immobilization list, if the owner files a written demand for a hearing with the village chief of police within 14 days after issuance of the notice specified in section 94-128 or within 14 days of the immobilization, whichever is later. A hearing shall be conducted by the chief of police within 48 hours of receipt of a written demand for hearing, unless otherwise mutually agreed by the parties. Failure to request or attend a scheduled hearing shall be deemed a waiver of the right to a hearing. In event of such failure, any amount deposited pursuant to section 94-127 shall be forfeited. A hearing provided by this section shall not determine the validity of or otherwise adjudicate any citation or notice of parking violation issued relative to the immobilized vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(9), 1-23-2002; Ord. No. 1810-14, § 3, 10-22-2014) 
Sec. 94-130. - Fees. 
    The fee for immobilization, the fee for towing subsequent to immobilization, and the storage fee shall be as established in section 38-94, provided that no fees shall be assessed for any immobilization or tow which has been determined to be erroneous. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(10), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-131. - Relocation of immobilized vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful to relocate or tow any vehicle restrained by an immobilizing device without the approval of the village chief of police. The registered owner of the immobilized vehicle and any person who relocates an immobilized vehicle in violation of this section shall each be subject to a penalty of $500.00 for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1377-02, § 1(11), 1-23-2002) 
Sec. 94-132. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 94-133. - Automated traffic law violations. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted an Automated Traffic Law Enforcement System of the Village of Norridge. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article for a vehicle to disregard a traffic control device or turn on red in violation of 625 ILCS 5/11-306, as adopted by reference in section 94-2 of this chapter, and a violation of chapter 94, section 94-148 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-134. - Definitions. 
    Whenever used in this division, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automated traffic law enforcement system or system means a device as set forth in 625 ILCS 5/11/208.6, located within the Village of Norridge with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red light signal to produce recorded images of a motor vehicle entering an intersection against a steady red or flashing red signal indicating a violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-306) as adopted by reference in section 94-2 of this chapter, and a violation of chapter 94, section 94-148 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002. The automated traffic law enforcement system is designed to obtain a clear recorded image of a violating motor vehicle and its license plate. The automated traffic law enforcement system shall not be used to record vehicle speeds or to enforce speed limit regulations. 
    Automated traffic law violation means a violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/11-306) as adopted by reference in section 94-2 of this chapter, and a violation of chapter 94, section 94-148, of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002, as recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system. 
    Certified report means a report concerning five or more unpaid fines or penalties for automated traffic law violations made by the village to the secretary of state in accordance with Section 6-306.5 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/6-306.5). 
    Hearing officer shall have the definition set forth in chapter 2, section 2-553 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002. 
    Ordinance administrator shall have the definition set forth in chapter 2, Section 2-553 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002. 
    Recorded images means images recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system, which consist of either two or more photographs, two or more microphotographs, two or more electronic images or a video recording showing the motor vehicle, together with at least one clearly recorded image identifying the vehicle's license plate. The recorded image shall also display the time, date and location of the violation. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-135. - Administrative hearing system. 
    All automated traffic law violations described under this division shall be adjudicated pursuant to the village's administrative hearing system, as set forth in chapter 2, article VII, and the regulations of chapter 94, article II, of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-136. - Signage. 
    Any intersection equipped with an automated traffic law enforcement system shall have a sign posted which is clearly visible to approaching traffic indicating that the intersection is being monitored by an automated traffic law enforcement system. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-137. - Processing and notice of automated traffic law violations. 
(a)  Notice of violation; review. When the automated traffic law enforcement system records a motor vehicle entering an intersection against a steady red or flashing red signal indication, in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or chapter 94, section 94-148 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002, the ordinance administrator shall, for each violation recorded, issue a written notice of the violation to the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle as the alleged violator. Prior to service of a notice of violation, the associated recorded image shall be reviewed by a technician employed or contracted by the village, who shall inspect the image and determine whether the motor vehicle was being operated in violation of Section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, or chapter 94, section 94-148 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge-2002, and whether one of the defenses enumerated herein is applicable upon inspection of the recorded image. Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation and that no defense applies, the notice of violation shall be served upon the registered vehicle owner or lessee in the manner herein provided. 
(b)  Contents of notice. Each notice of an automated traffic law violation shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, as indicated by the records of the Illinois Secretary of State, or, if such information is outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded in a United States Post Office approved database; 
(2)  The registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation; 
(3)  The violation charged; 
(4)  The location where the violation occurred; 
(5)  The date and time of the violation; 
(6)  A copy of the recorded images; 
(7)  The amount of the civil penalty imposed and the date by which the civil penalty shall be paid if liability for the violation is not going to be contested; 
(8)  A statement that the recorded images are evidence of a violation of a red light signal violation; 
(9)  A warning that failure to either pay the civil penalty or to contest liability is an admission of liability and may result in a suspension of the driving privileges of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle in addition to other specified penalties for failing to appear at the hearing or pay the fine in advance of the hearing; 
(10)  A statement that the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle may elect to proceed either by paying the fine stated in the notice of violation or by challenging the charge in an administrative hearing following the procedures set forth in subsection (c) herein; 
(11)  The make of the vehicle, if readily discernable from the recorded image; and 
(12)  The date, time and location of the administrative hearing at which the charge may be contested on its merits. 
(c)  Written request for a hearing. Upon issuance of the initial violation, the village shall notify the defendant in writing that defendant may, in lieu of paying the fine provided in the initial violation notice, file a written request for a hearing before the hearing officer within 21 days of the issuance of the initial violation notice. If the defendant does not pay the fine or request a hearing on the initial violation within 21 days of issuance, the village shall notify the defendant in writing of the date on which the hearing officer will enter a determination of liability against defendant for the violation(s) unless defendant files a written request for a hearing on the initial violation notice within ten days of the date for entry of the determination of liability. 
(d)  Delivery. The notice shall be delivered by first class mail, postage prepaid, within 30 days after the Illinois Secretary of State notifies the village of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, but in no event later than 90 days after the violation. 
(e)  Copies retained. The ordinance administrator or other duly appointed official shall retain a copy of all violation notices, recorded images and other correspondence mailed to the alleged violator. 
(f)  Prima facie case. Each notice of violation shall be evidence of the facts contained in the notice and shall establish prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in chapter 94, section 94-138. Each notice is admissible in any proceeding alleging an automated traffic law violation. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-138. - Defenses. 
    The hearing officer may consider in defense of an automated traffic law violation: 
(a)  That the motor vehicle or registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the control of or in the possession of the owner at the time of the red light signal violation. This defense must be demonstrated through the submission of proof that a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner; or 
(b)  That the driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the light was red either to yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle or as part of a funeral procession. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-139. - Penalty. 
(a)  Penalty. Unless the driver of the motor vehicle in question received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer at the time of the alleged automated traffic law violation, a motor vehicle owner or lessee shall be subject to a civil penalty not exceeding $100.00 for a proved violation of this division, plus an additional penalty of not more $100.00 for failure to pay the original penalty or contest the violation at an administrative hearing in a timely manner, if the motor vehicle is recorded by an automated traffic law enforcement system. Any penalty imposed for a violation of this division is a civil penalty and is not a violation of a traffic regulation governing the movement of motor vehicles and shall not be transmitted to the Illinois Secretary of State to be recorded on the driving record of the vehicle owner. 
(b)  Unpaid fine or penalty; driver's license suspension. Any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on five or more violations of the automated traffic law system may subject the person liable to suspension of his or her driver's license in accordance with the notice and procedures set forth in chapter 2, article 7 of the of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
Sec. 94-140. - Confidentiality. 
    Recorded images made by the automatic traffic enforcement system shall be confidential and shall be made available only to the alleged violator, and governmental and law enforcement agencies, for purposes of adjudicating automated traffic law violations, or for statistical or other governmental purposes. Any recorded image evidencing an automated traffic law violation, however, may be admissible in any proceeding resulting from the issuance of the citation for such violation. 
(Ord. No. 1628-09, § 2, 1-14-2009) 
ARTICLE III. - VEHICLE OPERATION[5] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference- Rules of the road, 625 ILCS 5/11-101 et seq. 

Sec. 94-141. - Speed limits. 
A.  The speed limit on all streets within the village limits, other than state and county roads, shall be a maximum of 20 miles per hour, unless posted otherwise. 
B.  The speed limit on Montrose Avenue from Cumberland to Ozanam Avenue shall be a maximum of 35 miles per hour. The speed limit on Montrose Avenue from Ozanam Avenue to Harlem Avenue shall be a maximum of 30 miles per hour. 
C.  No person shall drive a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of 20 miles per hour while passing a school zone, or while traveling upon any public thoroughfare on or across which children pass along to and from school during school days, when school children are present. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 4, §§ 12(e), (f), 33) 
State Law reference- Speed limits generally, 625 ILCS 5/11-601 et seq.; local alteration of speed limits, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(10), 5/11-208.2, 5/11-604; speed limits in school zones, 625 ILCS 5/11-605. 
Sec. 94-142. - Driving off thoroughfare. 
    No person shall ride or drive any vehicle for pleasure or business on or across any median strip or lawn, where there is no regular approach to the same. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 4, § 6) 
Sec. 94-143. - Obstruction of traffic. 
    No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon any street in such a manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 4, § 5) 
Sec. 94-144. - Loud or unnecessary noise. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle upon the street which makes an unusually loud or unnecessary noise. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 4, § 9) 
Sec. 94-145. - Toy vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates, a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle to go upon any roadway other than a crosswalk. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 1, § 8) 
Sec. 94-146. - Leaving, tracking or depositing mud on streets. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle so as to leave, track or otherwise deposit mud upon the streets of the village. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 3, § 18(c)) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Spilling loads on vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/15-109. 
Sec. 94-147. - Turning movements. 
    The following turning restrictions shall be observed: 
1.  Traffic moving east on Giddings Street may turn right only at Courtland Avenue between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
2.  Traffic moving east on Leland Avenue may turn right only at Courtland Avenue between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
3.  Traffic moving north on Courtland Avenue shall not make a left turn onto Giddings Street between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
4.  Traffic moving north on Courtland Avenue shall not make a left turn onto Leland Avenue between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
5.  Traffic moving south on Courtland Avenue shall not make a right turn onto Giddings Street between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
6.  Traffic moving south on Courtland Avenue shall not make a right turn onto Leland Avenue between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
7.  Traffic moving northbound on Harlem Avenue shall not make a left turn onto Agatite Avenue at any time. 
8.  Traffic moving eastbound on Agatite Avenue shall not make a left turn onto Harlem Avenue at any time. 
9.  Traffic moving northbound on Monterey Drive and on Moreland Drive shall not make a left turn onto westbound Foster Avenue at any time. 
10.  Traffic moving westbound on Foster Avenue man not turn left onto Moreland Drive nor onto Monterey Drive at any time. 
11.  Southbound Moreland Drive and southbound Monterey Drive are accessible only by traffic moving eastbound on Foster Avenue and by right turn only. 
12.  Traffic exiting the parking lot of the Mid-America Bank located on the southwest corner of Harlem and Montrose Avenues shall not make a right turn onto Pensacola Avenue. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6-A, § 2; Ord. No. 1339-01, § 1, 5-9-2001) 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict turns, 625 ILCS 5/11-207, 11-208(a)(9), 5/11-208.2; turning movements, 625 ILCS 5/11-801 et seq.

B.  [Reserved.] 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 5, § 7; Ord. No. 1544-06, § 2, 5-10-2006; Ord. No. 1651-09, § 2, 8-26-2009; Ord. No. 1756-12, § 2, 9-26-2012)

Sec. 94-151. - One-way streets for vehicular traffic. 
    The following streets are one-way streets as designated: 
1.  Wilson Avenue from Ozanam to Oriole Avenue, eastbound only. 
2.  Sunnyside Avenue from Nottingham Avenue to Harlem Avenue, westbound only. 
3.  Maple Avenue between Thatcher Avenue and Cumberland Avenue, westbound only. 
4.  Octavia Avenue between Irving Park Road and Berteau Avenue, northbound only. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 21; Ord. No. 1325-00, § 1, 11-22-2000; Ord. No. 1404-02, § 1, 5-23-2002; Ord. No. 1430-02, § 2, 12-11-2002) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Authority to designate one-way streets, 625 ILCS 5/11-207, 5/11-208(a)4, 5/11-208.2, 5/11-708(a); operation of vehicles on one-way streets, 625 ILCS 5/11-708(b). 
Sec. 94-152. - Restrictions on trucks; vehicle weight. 
A.  Whenever official signs are erected prohibiting the use of any street or part of a street by trucks or other commercial vehicles, or imposing set limitations upon such vehicles using the street or part of a street as authorized in this section, no person shall drive a truck or other commercial vehicle upon any such street or part of a street in violation of any such signs, except for the purpose of delivering or picking up materials or merchandise, and then only by entering such street at the intersection nearest the destination of the vehicle and proceeding thereon no farther than the nearest intersection thereafter. 
B.  No operator of a bus or vehicle designed and used for pulling or carrying freight or merchandise shall drive such vehicle on any village street except on Cumberland Avenue, Lawrence Avenue, Harlem Avenue, Irving Park Road and Montrose Avenue, unless the operator has deliveries or pickups of materials or persons to make on such street. 
C.  The following streets are declared to be boulevards for the use of passenger vehicular traffic only: Oriole Avenue running from Montrose to Lawrence Avenue. 
D.  No through truck traffic shall enter Newland Avenue running south from Montrose Avenue. 
E.  No vehicle or combination of vehicles equipped with pneumatic tires shall be operated, unladen or with load, upon residential streets and Montrose Avenue from Cumberland to Oketo in the village when the gross weight on the road surface through any axle exceeds 10,000 pounds. 
F.  Semi-tractor trailer truck traffic on Octavia Avenue shall be restricted as follows: 
1.  There shall be no southbound semi-tractor trailer truck traffic on Octavia Avenue between Montrose and Berteau Avenues. 
2.  Northbound semi-tractor trailer truck traffic shall be permitted on Octavia Avenue for deliveries to businesses located between Irving Park Road (at a point from the intersection of Forest Preserve Drive, Irving Park Road and Octavia Avenue) and Cullom Avenue. Said trucks will continue north on Octavia to exit onto Montrose Avenue. 
3.  Semi-tractor trailer trucks shall not make westbound turns off of Octavia Avenue onto Montrose, Belleplaine, Berteau, Pensacola or Cullom Avenues. 
4.  Semi-tractor trailer trucks shall not make eastbound turns off of Octavia Avenue onto Cullom or Pensacola Avenues. 
5.  Semi-tractor trailer trucks shall not make westbound turns off of Harlem Avenue onto Cullom or Pensacola Avenues. 
6.  There shall be no semi-tractor trailer truck parking, stopping or standing on Octavia Avenue between Irving Park Road (at a point from the intersection of Forest Preserve Drive, Irving Park Road and Octavia Avenue) and Montrose Avenue. 
    Nothing set forth herein shall restrict any truck or other commercial vehicle from providing service to the residences located on Octavia Avenue or residences located on any other street, in accordance with existing regulations or future amendments to the village's general regulations regarding traffic, use of village streets, trucks or commercial vehicles. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 1, § 14, ch. 9, art. 4, §§ 23, 31, 32(b); Ord. No. 1767-13, § 2, 3-13-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority to restrict vehicle weight or trucks, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(7), 5/11-208.2, 5/15-316(c); weight limits, 625 ILCS 5/15-111 et seq. 
Sec. 94-153. - Use of streets for farm equipment or other machinery which may cause damages. 
    No tractor, traction engine, motor truck or other similar vehicle shall be operated across, over or along any street in the village, if any such vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any block, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug or any projection of metal or wood which projects radically beyond the tread or traffic surface of the tire. This section shall not apply to tractors or traction engines equipped with what is known as crawler type tractors, when the same does not contain any projections of any kind likely to injure the surface of the road, nor to tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles which have upon their road wheels V-shaped, diagonal or other cleats arranged in such a manner as to be continuously in contact with the road surface. In no event shall the surface of any street be used as an area or space for turning any tractor or other farm machinery in carrying on or performing any farming operations upon the adjacent land. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the operation of tractors, traction engines or motor trucks across any street in order to reach adjacent lands if the street is protected by putting down solid planks or other suitable devices to prevent such vehicle from injuring the surface of the street. 
(Code 1972, ch. 6, art. 1, § 20) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Planking streets required in certain instances, 625 ILCS 5/15-108. 
Sec. 94-154. - Motor driven cycles. 
A.  For the purpose of this section, motor driven or electric cycles are defined as any motorcycle, motor scooter, motorized pedal cycle, or motor driven skateboard with less than 150 cubic centimeter displacement, or electric scooter, electric pedal driven cycle or electric skateboard. 
B.  No person shall operate motor driven or electric cycles upon any public or private street, public sidewalk, parking lot, bike path or public park. 
C.  A peace officer who cites a person for a violation of this section may impound any motor driven or electric cycle used by the person in the commission of the offense. The person or owner may recover the motor driven or electric cycle from the impound after a minimum of 24 hours after citation upon payment of a fee of $100.00. This $100.00 fee includes the costs incurred by the village to remove the motor driven or electric cycle to the impound. Upon the presentation of a signed court order by the person whose motor driven or electric cycle was impounded showing that the person has been acquitted of the offense or that the charges have been dismissed against the person for that offense, the village shall refund the $100.00 fee to the person or owner who paid such fee. 
D.  Exemptions. 
1.  Any police vehicle, fire vehicle, village vehicle or park district vehicle driven by an employee in the course of his/her duties shall be permitted to use any public or private street, parking lot, sidewalk, bike path or public park when it is necessary in the performance of his/her duties. 
2.  Motorized wheelchairs and any other motor driven or electric cycle that is specifically subject to Article 11 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
E.  That any person, firm or corporation guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $750.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1410-02, § 2, 8-14-2002) 
Secs. 94-155-94-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate standing and parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-207, 5/11-208(a)(1), 5/11-208.2; stopping, standing and parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-181. - Violation of article provisions; impounding of vehicles. 
A.  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall be fined for each such offense an amount set forth in this Code and may have his or her driving privileges suspended or revoked by the secretary of state for a period of time determined by the secretary of state for ten or more unpaid fines or penalties for violations of 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3 as referenced in 625 ILCS 5/11-306.5, or chapter 94, article II, division 1, section 94-41 D. and chapter 94, article IV, divisions 1, 2 and 3 of the Revised Municipal Code of the Village of Norridge - 2002, in addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under this article. 
B.  Every vehicle parked in violation of this article is declared to be a nuisance which may be abated by any police officer by removing and conveying such vehicle to the vehicle pound designated by the village board. Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any legally impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove the vehicle, he shall pay the administrative fees provided for herein to the village, furnish evidence of ownership or right to possession, and shall pay for the cost of storage for each day or fraction of a day in such pound. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 11; Ord. No. 1626-08, § 2, 11-12-2008; Ord. No. 1666-09, § 3, 12-9-2009) 
Sec. 94-182. - Vehicle owner responsibility. 
    Whenever any vehicle shall have been parked in violation of any provisions of this article prohibiting or restricting parking, the person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be prima facie responsible for such violation and subject to penalty therefor; provided, however, that no person who is the lessor of a vehicle pursuant to a written lease agreement shall be liable for the violation of any parking or standing regulation involving such vehicle during the period of the lease. Upon the request of the village, received within 120 days after the violation has occurred, the lessor shall provide, within 60 days after such receipt, the name and address of the lessee. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 12) 
State Law reference- Parking liability of lessor of vehicle, 625 ILCS 5/11-1306; duty of lessor of vehicle upon receiving notice of parking violation, 625 ILCS 5/11-1305. 
Sec. 94-183. - Unattended vehicle. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition and removing the key, or when standing upon any perceptible grade without effectively setting the brake thereon and turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1401. 
Sec. 94-184. - Parking position in relation to curb or shoulder. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked with the righthand wheels parallel to and within 12 inches of the righthand curb, or as close as practicable to the right edge of the righthand shoulder. 
B.  Except when otherwise provided by local ordinance, every vehicle stopped or parked upon a one-way roadway shall be so stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway, in the direction of authorized traffic movement, with its righthand wheels within 12 inches of the righthand curb or as close as practicable to the right edge of the righthand shoulder, or with its lefthand wheels within 12 inches of the lefthand curb or as close as practicable to the left edge of the lefthand shoulder. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1304. 
Sec. 94-185. - Parking to load or unload. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle, except a private passenger vehicle with a seating capacity of not more than ten passengers, on any street, or in any automobile off-street parking area, for a longer period than is necessary for the reasonably expeditious loading and unloading of such vehicle. Except that the parking of trucks as an accessory use when used in the conduct of a permitted business in the zoned district shall be limited to vehicles of not over 11/2 tons capacity when located within 150 feet of a residence district boundary line. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 5) 
Sec. 94-186. - Display of parked vehicle or merchandise in parked vehicle for sale. 
    It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon which merchandise is being offered to the public for sale. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 6) 
Sec. 94-187. - Commercial vehicles on residential streets; hours permitted. 
    No person shall park or cause or permit a commercial vehicle to stand on any residential street, alley, public way or parkway in the village between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 9) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 94-188. - Snow on streets. 
A.  It shall be unlawful, where parking is not otherwise prohibited, for any person to stop, stand or park or leave unattended a motor vehicle on any public street in the village, after three inches of snow have fallen, until the snow has been removed. 
B.  All motor vehicles in violation of the provisions of this section will be subject to being towed away at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 10) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82. 
Sec. 94-189. - Reserved. 
Sec. 94-190. - Residents' parking only. 
A.  General restrictions. It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle at any time on those sections of residential streets listed in subsection C. of this section, except that residents of the village and their guests may park their own private passenger vehicles on those sections of residential streets listed in subsection C. of this section without restriction unless restricted or prohibited elsewhere in this chapter. 
Only residents of Norridge who live on blocks designated with resident only parking signs may purchase annual guest parking passes or obtain the free one-day guest parking passes. 
Every resident of the Village of Norridge must display a valid vehicle sticker on his or her vehicle, regardless of where the vehicle is parked within the village. Village residents may not display a guest parking pass in lieu of a valid vehicle sticker. 
B.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Guest means any person who visits or calls upon a resident of the village, but does not stay or reside in such abode beyond the limits established by the state statutes and/or this Code regarding registration or licensing of the guest's vehicle. Guests are not permitted to park on streets restricted to resident parking only unless they have a valid, current, guest parking pass issued by the village. 
    Private passenger vehicles means, but is not necessarily limited to, automobiles, motorcycles, motorized conveyances, passenger vans and certain trucks and recreational vehicles which are owned, leased, rented or borrowed by residents of the village. 
    Resident means any person who owns, leases, rents or otherwise occupies an abode within the corporate limits of the village for some portions of each calendar year, but such status may be claimed only during the actual term of each occupancy. The proper display of a valid, current, vehicle sticker issued by the Village of Norridge will be accepted as proof of residency. 
C.  Resident only parking. Resident only parking shall be on the following streets:

(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 27; Ord. No. 1260, § 1, 5-26-1999; Ord. No. 1312-00, § 1, 8-9-2000; Ord. No. 1344-01, § 1, 5-23-2001; Ord. No. 1350-01, § 5, 7-11-2001; Ord. No. 1683-10, § 2, 8-11-2010; Ord. No. 1768-13, §§ 2, 3, 3-27-2013; Ord. No. 1853-16, § 2, 6-22-2016; Ord. No. 1891-17, § 2, 4-12-2017) 
Sec. 94-191. - Use of municipal parking lots. 
A.  Passenger vehicles bearing a valid village vehicle sticker may be parked in the Municipal Parking Lot at Irving Park Road and Oketo Avenue between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Commercial vehicles bearing a valid village vehicle sticker must obtain and display proof of written permission to park overnight in that lot. 
B.  Any vehicle legally parked in the Municipal Parking Lot at Irving Park Road and Oketo Avenue must be removed from the lot at least every 48 hours, except with written permission. 
C.  No maintenance or repair of any vehicle shall be performed in any Municipal Parking Lot. 
D.  Any vehicle not legally licensed or any vehicle in disrepair will be considered to be abandoned and will be towed at the owner's expense from any Municipal Parking Lot. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 30; Ord. No. 1710-11, § 2, 6-22-2011) 
Sec. 94-192. - Parking within marked lines. 
    Where lines are marked upon pavement indicating where vehicles are to be parked, no person shall park a vehicle except within such lines. 
Sec. 94-193. - Parking in spaces marked no parking. 
    No person shall park a motor vehicle in any space marked as no parking by diagonal lines that are blue, yellow or white in color. 
Sec. 94-194. - Regulation of parking generally. 
A.  When the board of trustees has designated, by signs or markings, areas in which parking is prohibited, or prohibited during certain hours, or limited in time, or otherwise regulated or restricted, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any such sign or marking. 
B.  This section shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle which is disabled on the paved, improved or main traveled portion of a highway in such manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving such disabled vehicle in such position. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 3) 
Sec. 94-195. - Prohibited in certain places; exception. 
A.  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
1.  On a sidewalk; 
2.  In front of a public or private driveway; 
3.  Within an intersection; 
4.  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
5.  On a crosswalk; 
6.  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
7.  Within 30 feet upon the approach of any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of the roadway; 
8.  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless state department of transportation or this village, under their respective jurisdiction, indicate a different length by signs or markings; 
9.  Within 20 feet of a driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of such entrance when properly signposted; 
10.  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
11.  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
12.  On private property without the consent of the owner of such property; 
B.  No person other than a police officer shall move a vehicle into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful or start or cause to be started the motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change or move the levers, brake, starting device, gears or other mechanism of a standing motor vehicle to a position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver, or attempt to do so. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1303.

Sec. 94-197. - Bus stops. 
A.  No vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a bus stop. 
B.  The village engineer is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops on such public streets in such places and in such number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
C.  It shall be unlawful to stand or park a vehicle, other than a bus, at a bus stop. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine as established in this Code. The fine shall be initially established at $25.00 per violation. 
(Ord. No. 1465-03, § 2, 11-12-2003) 
Sec. 94-198. - Truck parking in residential areas prohibited. 
    There shall be no truck parking in residential areas of the village on streets or on driveways except as follows: 
A.  Vehicles eligible for exception must: 
1.  Have valid state license plates indicating a "B" truck or passenger usage; 
2.  Have no more than one rear axle; 
3.  Any attached auxiliary equipment including, but not limited to, equipment racks, storage boxes, and/or lockers, may not extend beyond the front, rear or sides of the vehicle. Equipment, not longer than the vehicle, may be on the equipment rack when parked outside the garage. No snow plows on the vehicle when parked outside the garage; 
4.  Not contain any debris, material or equipment associated with a business or profession; and 
5.  In cargo and panel vans with seating behind the driver, have side windows adjacent to all of the seats. 
B.  Except with the prior written permission of the Norridge Police Department, only one eligible vehicle per residence is qualified to be parked on residential property at any one time provided it is: 
1.  Parked in a garage; or 
2.  If no garage space is available: 
a.  If the residence has a side driveway, the eligible vehicle must be parked between the front line of the home and the rear line of the home (neither in the front nor rear yards); 
b.  If the residence has a driveway but not a side driveway, then the eligible vehicle must be parked within five feet of the main vehicle door to the garage; 
c.  If the residence has an alley, but no driveway, then the eligible vehicle must be parked in an approved rear parking space. 
C.  Except with the prior written permission of the Norridge Police Department, there shall be no parking of any commercial trucks, regardless of eligibility, on any residential street between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. or anytime on the south side of Wilson Avenue from the East Property line of Oriole Avenue east 633 feet to the Village limits. 
D.  Any violation of this section shall be fined not less than $250.00 nor more than $1,000.00 per violation. Every day that this section is violated shall constitute a different violation. 
(Ord. No. 1479-04, § 2, 5-12-2004; Ord. No. 1914-18, § 2, 1-24-2018) 
Sec. 94-199. - Boat, trailer, camper, recreational vehicles and derelict vehicle parking in residential areas prohibited. 
    There shall be no parking of boats, trailers, campers, recreational vehicles or derelict vehicles in the residential areas of the village. 
A.  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms shall be defined as they are in the Illinois Vehicle Code or, if not defined in the Illinois Vehicle Code, as follows: 
1.  Boat: A vehicle designed or used to travel on or through water. 
2.  Trailer: A vehicle without motive power in operation, other than a pole trailer, designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing vehicle. (625 ILCS 5/1-209). 
3.  Camper: A truck camper or camping trailer, as follows: Either a trailer, not used commercially, constructed with partial side walls which fold for towing and unfold to provide temporary living quarters for recreational camping or travel use or a truck, not used commercially, when equipped with a portable unit designed to be loaded into the bed which is constructed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, travel or camping use. (625 ILCS 5/1-109.01 and 5/1-211.01). 
4.  Recreational vehicle: Every camping trailer, motor home, mini-motor home, travel trailer, truck camper or van camper used primarily for recreational purposes and not used commercially nor owned by a commercial business. (625 ILCS 5/1-169). 
5.  Derelict vehicle: Any inoperable, unregistered, discarded motor vehicle, regardless of title, having lost its character as a substantial property and left without justification on the owner's land contrary to the public policy expressed in Section 4-301 of this [Vehicle] Code. (625 ILCS 115.07). 
6.  Parking: The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than when temporarily and actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. (625 ILCS 5/1-156). 
B.  There are three exceptions to the general prohibition listed in paragraph A., above. They are: 
1.  With the prior approval of the Norridge Police Department, a boat on a trailer, a camper or a motor home may park on a driveway or street in a residential area to load or unload during period of the loading and unloading, which period shall not exceed 24 hours. 
2.  With the prior approval of the Norridge Police Department, guests of Norridge residents may park on a driveway or residential street for a period not to exceed 72 hours. 
3.  Parking of boats, campers, trailers and recreational vehicles is permitted in residential garages. Provided, however, the boat, camper, trailer or recreational vehicle must be totally enclosed within the residential garage and the doors to the garage must be shut. 
C.  Any violation of this section shall be fined not less than $250.00 nor more than $1,000.00 per violation. Every day that this section is violated shall constitute a different violation. 
(Ord. No. 1479-04, § 3, 5-12-2004) 
Sec. 94-200. - Parking of portable storage units. 
    On-street parking of portable storage units is permitted for a limited time only as follows: 
A.  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Portable storage unit: (also known as PODS or portable on-demand storage structure) means a large container, storage unit, packing crate, other portable structure, or enclosed trailer used for moving purposes, which is transportable and is designed and used for the temporary storage of household goods, personal items and other materials used in moving from one place to another. 
B.  Location and purpose. 
1.  A portable storage unit shall be placed next to the curb only in front of the address from where the occupant is either moving in or moving out. It is not intended for additional storage at that address, however temporary in nature. 
2.  The outermost edge of the portable storage unit shall extend no further than ten feet from the curb. 
3.  Portable storage units shall not be parked so as to impede access to fire hydrants and shall comply with all village regulations prohibiting the parking, standing, or stopping of vehicles within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
C.  Permit required. 
1.  It shall be unlawful to park a portable storage unit on any village street without first having obtained a permit to do so from the village pursuant to this section. 
2.  All permits (including renewal permits) expire 72 hours from the time of issuance. 
3.  A permit is renewable for a location only one time in a six-month period (commencing with the original issuance date). 
4.  The permit fee shall be as set forth in chapter 38 of this Code. 
5.  Only one portable storage unit may be placed on a village street in front of a residential property at one time. 
D.  Specifications. A portable storage unit must conform to the following: 
1.  It must be completely enclosed; 
2.  The portable storage unit owner's name, address and 24-hour phone number must be clearly marked on the portable storage unit in reflective letters and numbers; 
3.  There must be lighted barricades in the front and in the rear of the portable storage unit, on the sides that face traffic. Said barricades are to be provided by the unit owner and must be in working condition. Alternatively, reflective tape of at least two inches in width must be affixed to the entire vertical surface of the corner of the portable storage unit on any side facing a public street or public right-of-way. A village permit, protected from the elements, shall be attached to the side of the portable storage unit facing the street. 
E.  Maximum time on street. The maximum time that a portable storage unit may remain on the street is 72 continuous hours from the time the permit is issued. 
F.  Insurance required. Any vendor providing a portable storage unit in the village must have a village license and must provide a $1,000,000.00 insurance policy naming the Village of Norridge as additional insured for each portable storage unit delivered. 
G.  Penalty for violation of section. Any person convicted of any violation of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $200.00 and not more than $1,000.00 for each offense. Each day is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1594-07, § 2, 10-24-2007) 
Sec. 94-201. - Valid state vehicle registration required for parking. 
A.  Valid registration required. It shall be unlawful to operate or park a vehicle with expired registration on any street within the Village of Norridge. For purposes of this section, a current, valid, registration issued by any state is sufficient. 
B.  Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, for each occurrence, be subject to the penalty set forth in chapter 1 subsection 9(f) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1650-09, § 1, 8-12-2009; Ord. No. 1920-18, § 9, 3-28-2018) 
Secs. 94-202-94-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES 

Sec. 94-221. - Parking privileges. 
    A motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a person with disabilities, as defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-159.1, pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609 or a special decal or device issued pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2 or a motor vehicle registered in another jurisdiction, state, district, territory or foreign country upon which is displayed a registration plate, special decal or device issued by the other jurisdiction designating the vehicle is operated by or for a person with disabilities shall be exempt from any statute or ordinance imposing time limitations on parking, except limitations of one-half hour or less, on any street or highway zone, or any parking lot or parking place which are owned, leased or owned and leased by the village; and shall be recognized as a valid license plate or parking device and shall receive the same parking privileges as residents of this state. Such vehicle shall be subject to the laws which prohibit parking in no stopping and no standing zones in front of or near fire hydrants, driveways, public building entrances and exits, bus stops and loading areas, and is prohibited from parking where the motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard, whereby such motor vehicle shall be moved at the instruction and request of a law enforcement officer to a location designated by the officer. Any motor vehicle bearing registration plates or a special decal or device specified in this section or in 625 ILCS 5/3-616, or such parking device as specifically authorized in 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2 as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a person with disabilities or disabled veteran, may park, in addition to any other lawful place, in any parking place specifically reserved for such vehicles by the posting of an official sign as provided under 625 ILCS 5/11-301. Parking privileges granted by this section are strictly limited to the person to whom the special registration plates, special decal or device were issued and to qualified operators acting under his express direction while the person with disabilities is present. A person to whom privileges were granted shall, at the request of a police officer or any other person invested by law with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic, present an identification card with a picture as verification that the person is the person to whom the special registration plates, special decal or device was issued. Such parking privileges granted by this section are also extended to motor vehicles of not-for-profit organizations used for the transportation of persons with disabilities when such motor vehicles display the decal or device issued pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2. No person shall use any area for the parking of any motor vehicle pursuant to section 94-195 or where an official sign controlling such area expressly prohibits parking at any time or during certain hours. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 1532-06, § 2, adopted Jan. 11, 2006, repealed § 94-223, which pertained to harking for handicapped persons; violation and derived from Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 29; Ord. No. 1393-02, §§ 1, 2, adopted March 14, 2002. 
Sec. 94-224. - Disability parking; enforcement; penalty. 
A.  Parking prohibition. 
1.  It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing registration plates or decals or placards issued to a person with disabilities, as defined by 625 ILCS 5/1-159.1, pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-616, 5/11-1301.1 or 5/11-1301.2, or to a disabled veteran pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/3-609, as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a person with disabilities or disabled veteran, in any parking place, including any private or public off-street parking facility, specifically reserved, by the posting of an official sign as designated under 625 ILCS 5/11-301, for motor vehicles bearing such registration plates. Any motor vehicle bearing a disability license plate or a parking decal or device or placard containing the International symbol of access issued to persons with disabilities by any local authority, state, district, territory or foreign country shall be recognized as a valid license plate or device or placard and receive the same parking privileges as residents of this state. 
2.  An individual with a vehicle displaying disability license plates or a parking decal or device or placard issued to a qualified person with a disability under 625 ILCS 5/3-616, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1, or 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2 or to a disabled veteran under 625 ILCS 5/3-609 is in violation of this Section if (i) the person using the disability license plate or parking decal or device is not the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device or is not transporting the authorized holder of the disability license plate or parking decal or device to or from the parking location and (ii) the person uses the disability license plate or parking decal or device to exercise any privileges granted through the disability license plate or parking decals or devices under the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.). 
B.  Removal of vehicles. Any person or local authority owning or operating any public or private off-street parking facility may, after notifying the police or sheriff's department, remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety any vehicle parked within a stall or space reserved for use by a person with disabilities which does not display person with disabilities registration plates or a special decal or device as required under this section. 
C.  Fines and penalties. 
1.  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsection A-1 shall be fined for each such offense an amount set forth in chapter 38 of this Code, in addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under this section. 
2.  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsection A-2 shall be fined for each such offense an amount set forth in chapter 38 of this Code and may have his or her driving privileges suspended or revoked by the secretary of state for a period of time determined by the secretary of state. The secretary of state may also suspend or revoke the disability license plates or parking decal or device for a period of time determined by the secretary of state. 
D.  Authorized holder. As used in this section, the term "authorized holder" means an individual issued a disability license plate under 625 ILCS 5/3-616 or an individual issued a parking decal or device under 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.2, or an individual issued a disabled veteran's license plate under Section 3-609 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. 
(Code 1972, ch. 9, art. 6, § 28; Ord. No. 1532-06, § 2, 1-11-2006; Ord. No. 1626-08, § 3, 11-12-2008; Ord. No. 1655-09, § 2, 10-14-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.3.
